{{no footnotes|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox military unit | unit_name =1st Life Grenadier Regiment | native_name =''Första livgrenadjärregementet'' | image = | alt = | caption = | dates =1816–1927 | disbanded = | country ={{flag|Sweden}} | countries = | allegiance =[[Swedish Armed Forces]] | branch =[[Swedish Army]] | type =[[Infantry]] [[regiment]] | role = | size =[[Regiment]] | command_structure =2nd Military District (1833–1901)
II Army Division (1902–1927) | garrison =[[Linköping]] | garrison_label = | nickname = | patron = | motto = | colors = White | colors_label = | march ="Ryska grenadjärregementets 'Konungen av Preussen' marsch" (Schubert){{cite book |last=Sandberg |first=Bo |title=Försvarets marscher och signaler förr och nu: marscher antagna av svenska militära förband, skolor och staber samt igenkännings-, tjänstgörings- och exercissignaler |edition=New |year=2007 |publisher=Militärmusiksamfundet med Svenskt marscharkiv |location=Stockholm |language=Swedish |isbn=978-91-631-8699-8 |id={{LIBRIS|10413065}} |page=200}} (1845–1870, 1893–1927)
"Wiener Rekruten-Marsch" (1870–1883)
"Napoleonmarsch" (1883–1893) | mascot = | anniversaries = | equipment = | equipment_label = | battles = | decorations = | battle_honours =[[Battle of Lützen (1632)|Lützen]] (1632), [[Battle of Breitenfeld (1642)|Leipzig]] (1642), [[Battle of Helsingborg (1710)|Helsingborg]] (1710), [[Battle of Gadebusch|Gadebusch]] (1712), [[Battle of Valkeala|Valkeala]] (1790) | battle_honours_label = | flying_hours = | website = | current_commander = | commander1 = | commander1_label = | commander2 = | commander2_label = | commander3 = | commander3_label = | commander4 = | commander4_label = | commander5 = | commander5_label = | commander6 = | commander6_label = | commander7 = | commander7_label = | commander8 = | commander8_label = | commander9 = | commander9_label = | notable_commanders = | identification_symbol = | identification_symbol_label = | identification_symbol_2 = | identification_symbol_2_label = | identification_symbol_3 = | identification_symbol_3_label = | identification_symbol_4 = | identification_symbol_4_label = | identification_symbol_5 = | identification_symbol_5_label = }} The '''1st Life Grenadier Regiment''' ({{lang-sv|Första livgrenadjärregementet}}), designation '''I 4''', was a [[Swedish Army]] [[infantry]] [[regiment]] that traced its origins back to the 16th century. It was merged into a new regiment in 1927. The regiment's soldiers were recruited from the province of [[Östergötland]]. == History == {{seealso|Life Grenadier Regiment (Sweden)#History}} The regiment has its origins in [[fänika|fänikor]] (companies) raised in [[Östergötland]] in the 16th century. These units later formed [[Östergötland Infantry Regiment]] and [[Östergötland Cavalry Regiment]] which merged in 1791 and formed [[Life Grenadier Regiment (Sweden)|Life Grenadier Regiment]]. This regiment was split in 1816 creating 1st Life Grenadier Regiment and [[2nd Life Grenadier Regiment (Sweden)|2nd Life Grenadier Regiment]]. The regiment was [[Swedish allotment system|allotted]] in 1685. The regiment was given the designation I 4 (4th Infantry Regiment) in a [[general order]] in 1816. 1st Life Grenadier Regiment was then merged with 2nd Life Grenadier Regiment in 1928 to reform the old Life Grenadier Regiment. == Campaigns == {{seealso|Life Grenadier Regiment (Sweden)#Campaigns}} *None == Organisation == {{seealso|Life Grenadier Regiment (Sweden)#Organisation}} *? ==Commanding officers== Executive officers (''Sekundchef'') and regimental commander active at the regiment in the years 1816–1927. ''Sekundchef'' was a title used until 31 December 1974 at regiments that were part of the King's Life and Household Troops (''Kungl. Maj:ts Liv- och Hustrupper''). In the years 1816–1818, the Crown Prince was the regimental commander. In the years 1818–1927, His Majesty the King was the regimental commander.{{cite book |last=Kjellander |first=Rune |title=Sveriges regementschefer 1700-2000: chefsbiografier och förbandsöversikter |year=2003 |publisher=Probus |location=Stockholm |language=Swedish |isbn=91-87184-74-5 |id={{LIBRIS|8981272}} |page=259}} ===Regimental commander=== {{Div col}} *1816–1818: [[Charles XIV John of Sweden|Crown Price Charles John]] *1818–1844: [[Charles XIV John of Sweden|Charles XIV John]] *1844–1859: [[Oscar I of Sweden|Oscar I]] *1859–1872: [[Charles XV of Sweden|Charles XV]] *1872–1905: [[Oscar II of Sweden|Oscar II]] *1907–1927: [[Gustaf V of Sweden|Gustaf V]] {{Div col end}} ===Executive officers (''Sekundchefer'')=== {{Div col}} *1816–1832: C M Strömfelt *1832–1845: S von Post *1845–1848: C L von Hohenhausen *1848–1852: D M Klingspor *1852–1854: M Ahnström *1854–1858: J M Björnstjerna *1858–1871: C H Mörner *1871–1879: A G Örn *1879–1890: C A M Lagerfelt *1890–1898: P H W Reuterswärd *1898–1906: Per Henrik Edvard Brändström *1906–1914: Ernst Herman Daniel Vilhelm von Bornstedt *1914–1919: Carl Gustaf Valdemar Hammarskjöld *1919–1927: Kunt Otto Hjalmar Säfwenberg {{Div col end}} ==Names, designations and locations== {{seealso|Life Grenadier Regiment (Sweden)#Names, designations and locations}} {| class="wikitable" ! style="font-weight:bold;" | Location ! style="font-weight:bold;" | ! style="text-align: center; font-weight:bold;" | From ! ! style="text-align: center; font-weight:bold;" | To |- | [[Malmen Airbase|Malmen]] | | style="text-align: center;" | 1816-10-01 | style="text-align: center;" | – | style="text-align: center;" | 1922-10-?? |- | [[Linköping]] Garrison | | style="text-align: center;" | 1922-10-?? | style="text-align: center;" | – | style="text-align: center;" | 1927-12-31 |} ==See also== *[[List of Swedish regiments]] == References == {{Commonscat|Första livgrenadjärregementet|1st Life Grenadier Regiment}} ;Notes {{reflist}} ;Print *{{cite book |last=Braunstein |first=Christian |title=Sveriges arméförband under 1900-talet |year=2003 |publisher=Statens Försvarshistoriska Museer |location=Stockholm |isbn=91-971584-4-5}} *{{cite book |last=Holmberg |first=Björn |title=Arméns regementen, skolor och staber: en sammanställning |year=1993 |publisher=Svenskt militärhistoriskt bibliotek |location=Arvidsjaur |isbn=91-972209-0-6}} *{{cite book |last=Kjellander |first=Rune |title=Sveriges regementschefer 1700-2000: chefsbiografier och förbandsöversikter |year=2003 |publisher=Probus |location=Stockholm |isbn=91-87184-74-5}} *{{cite book |last=Nelsson |first=Bertil |title=Från Brunkeberg till Nordanvind: 500 år med svenskt infanteri |year=1993 |publisher=Probus |location=Stockholm |isbn=91-87184-23-0}} *{{cite book |title=Svensk rikskalender 1908 |url=http://runeberg.org/rikskal/1908/ |year=1908 |publisher=P.A. [[File:Russian Arctic claim.PNG|315px|thumb|alt=Map showing Russian claims in the Arctic. |Russia has an extensive sea bottom claim in the Arctic region. The large hashed area reflects Russia's current extended continental shelf claim]] The '''Arctic policy of Russia''' is the domestic and [[foreign policy]] of the [[Russian Federation]] with respect to [[Extreme North (Russia)|the Russian region]] of the [[Arctic]]. The Russian region of the Arctic is defined in the "Russian Arctic Policy" as all Russian possessions located north of the [[Arctic Circle]]. (About one-fifth of Russia's landmass is north of the Arctic Circle.) Russia is one of five countries bordering the [[Arctic Ocean]]. In 2011, out of 4 million inhabitants of the Arctic, roughly 2 million lived in arctic Russia, making it the largest arctic country by population. However, in recent years Russia's Arctic population has been declining.<ref name=Population>{{cite web | url= http://int.rgo.ru/arctic/arctic-overview/socio-demographic-situation-in-the-arctic/ | title= Socio-demographic situation in the Arctic |accessdate=2011-07-18}}</ref>
The main goals of Russia in its Arctic policy are to utilize its natural resources, protect its [[ecosystems]], use the seas as a transportation system in Russia's interests, and ensure that it remains a zone of peace and cooperation.<ref name=Russian_policy>{{cite web | url= http://www.arcticprogress.com/2010/11/russias-arctic-policy/ | title= Russia’s Arctic Policy To 2020 And Beyond |accessdate=2011-07-18}}</ref> Russia currently maintains a military presence in the Arctic and has plans to improve it, as well as strengthen the [[Border Guard Service of Russia|Border Guard/Coast Guard]] presence there. Using the Arctic for economic gain has been done by Russia for centuries for shipping and fishing. Russia has plans to exploit the large offshore resource deposits in the Arctic. The [[Northern Sea Route]] is of particular importance to Russia for transportation, and the Russian [[Security Council of Russia|Security Council]] is considering projects for its development. The Security Council also stated a need for increasing investment in Arctic infrastructure.<ref name="ITAR-TASS_August_Conference">{{cite web | url= http://www.itar-tass.com/en/c32/199500.html | title=RF ready to contribute to preserving unique Arctic nature - Medvedev| publisher = ITAR-TASS News Agency| date = August 6, 2011 |accessdate=2011-08-28}}</ref>
Russia conducts extensive research in the Arctic region, notably the [[manned drifting ice station]]s and the [[Arktika 2007]] expedition, which was the first to reach the seabed at the [[North Pole]]. The research is partly aimed to back up Russia's territorial claims, in particular those related to Russia's extended [[continental shelf]] in the Arctic Ocean.
==History== On October 1, 1987, USSR President Mikhail Gorbachev, delivered the Murmansk Initiative stating six goals of the Soviet Union's Arctic foreign policy: establish a nuclear-free zone in Northern Europe; reduce military activity in the Baltic, Northern, Norwegian and Greenland Seas; cooperate on resource development; form an international conference on Arctic scientific research coordination; cooperate in environmental protection and management; and open the Northern Sea Route.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alaskadispatch.com/article/how-gorbachev-shaped-future-arctic-policy-25-years-ago|title=Arctic - How Gorbachev shaped future Arctic policy 25 years ago|publisher=|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref>
==Geography== {| |[[Image:Kara Sea map.png|250px|alt=Map showing the Kara Sea.]] [[Image:East Siberian Sea map.png|410px|alt=Map showing the East Siberian Sea.]] |}
The Russian [[Ministry of Economic Development (Russia)|Ministry of Economic Development]] has identified eight Arctic Support Zones on which funds and projects will be focused, with the aim of fostering the economic potential of the [[Northern Sea Route]] while ensuring that the Russian presence will not be limited to [[resource extraction]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Technology and government's hand vital for Russian Arctic development|url=http://www.intellinews.com/technology-and-government-s-hand-vital-for-russian-arctic-development-119002/?source=russia|accessdate=6 April 2017|work=bne IntelliNews}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Russia’s Ministry of Economic Development wants 210 billion rubles for Arctic regions|url=http://www.rcinet.ca/eye-on-the-arctic/2017/03/07/russias-ministry-of-economic-development-wants-210-billion-rubles-for-arctic-regions/|website=Eye on the Arctic|accessdate=6 April 2017|date=7 March 2017}}</ref>
The eight zones are [[Kolsky District|Kola]], [[Arkhangelsk]], [[Nenets Autonomous Okrug|Nenets]], [[Vorkuta]], [[Yamalo-Nenets Autonomous Okrug|Yamal-Nenets]], [[Taimyr-Turukhan]], [[North Yakutia]] and [[Chukotka Autonomous Okrug|Chukotka]].<ref>{{cite news|title=About 40 Arctic projects may be in Russia's Yamal backbone zone — governor|url=http://tass.com/economy/933033|accessdate=6 April 2017|work=TASS|language=ru}}</ref> In the North Yakutia area, the project includes reconstruction of the [[Tiksi]] sea port and the port of [[Zelenomysky]].<ref>{{cite news|title=5 billion for development of Tiksi infrastructure|url=https://thebarentsobserver.com/en/industry-and-energy/2017/01/5-billion-development-tiksi-infrastructure|accessdate=6 April 2017|work=The Independent Barents Observer|language=en}}</ref> In the Arkhangelsk zone, this will include the construction of the {{ill|Belkomur Railway|ru|Белкомур}}.<ref name="nefte">{{cite news|title=В Минэкономразвития рассмотрели проекты 3 пилотных опорных зон развития арктической зоны РФ|url=http://neftegaz.ru/news/view/152108-V-Minekonomrazvitiya-rassmotreli-proekty-3-pilotnyh-opornyh-zon-razvitiya-arkticheskoy-zony-RF|accessdate=6 April 2017|publisher=Neftegaz|language=ru}}</ref>
==Exploration== {{See also|Arctic exploration}} The first recorded voyage to the Russian Arctic was by the [[Novgorod]]ian Uleb in 1032, in which he discovered the [[Kara Sea]]. From the 11th to the 16th centuries, Russian coastal dwellers of the [[White Sea]], or [[pomors]], gradually explored other parts of the Arctic coastline, going as far as the [[Ob River|Ob]] and [[Yenisei River|Yenisey]] rivers, establishing trading posts in [[Mangazeya]]. Continuing the search of [[fur]]s and [[walrus]] and [[mammoth]] [[ivory]], the [[Siberian Cossacks]] under [[Mikhail Stadukhin]] reached the [[Kolyma River]] by 1644. Ivan Moskvitin discovered the [[Sea of Okhotsk]] in 1639 and [[Fedot Alekseyev Popov]] and [[Semyon Dezhnyov]] discovered the [[Bering Strait]] in 1648,<ref name=exploration>{{cite web |author = Leonid Sverdlov| url= http://arcticcircle.uconn.edu/HistoryCulture/russianexplor.html |title= Russian Naval Officers and Geographic Exploration in Northern Russia (18th through 20th centuries)| publisher = Arctic Voice| date = November 27, 1996 |accessdate=2011-07-27| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110711223804/http://arcticcircle.uconn.edu/HistoryCulture/russianexplor.html| archivedate= 11 July 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> with Dezhnyov establishing a permanent Russian settlement near the present day [[Anadyr (town)|Anadyr]].
After [[Peter the Great|Peter I]] took the throne, Russia began to develop a [[Russian Navy|navy]] and use it to continue its Arctic exploration. [[Vitus Bering]] explored [[Kamchatka]] in 1728,<ref name=exploration /> while Bering's aides [[Ivan Fyodorov (navigator)|Ivan Fyodorov]] and [[Mikhail Gvozdev]] discovered [[Alaska]] in 1732. The [[Great Northern Expedition]], which lasted from 1733 to 1743, was one of the largest exploration enterprises in history, organized and led by [[Vitus Bering]], [[Aleksei Chirikov]] and a number of other major explorers. A party of the expedition personally led by Bering and Chirikov discovered southern [[Alaska]], the [[Aleutian Islands]] and the [[Commander Islands]],<ref name=northern_expedition1>{{cite web | url= http://www.pame.is/amsa/on-focus/53-the-great-northern-expedition |title= The Great Northern Expedition | publisher = Protection of the Arctic Marine Environment Working Group |accessdate=2011-07-27}}</ref> while the parties led by [[Stepan Malygin]], [[Dmitry Ovtsyn]], [[Fyodor Minin]], [[Semyon Chelyuskin]], [[Vasily Pronchischev]], [[Khariton Laptev]] and [[Dmitry Laptev]] mapped most of the Arctic coastline of Russia (from the White Sea in Europe to the mouth of Kolyma River in Asia).<ref name=northern_expedition2>{{cite web | url= http://www.whoi.edu/beaufortgyre/history/history_russian1819.html |title= Russian Northern Expeditions (18th-19th centuries)| publisher = Beaufort Gyre Exploration Project |accessdate=2011-07-27| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110718235225/http://www.whoi.edu/beaufortgyre/history/history_russian1819.html| archivedate= 18 July 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The expedition resulted in 62 large maps and charts of the Arctic region.<ref name=northern_expedition1 />
==Territorial claims==
Modern Russian territorial claims to the Arctic officially date back to April 15, 1926, when the Soviet Union claimed land between 32°04'35"E and 168°49'30"W. However, this claim specifically only applied to [[Russian Arctic islands|islands]] and lands within this region.<ref name=Soviet_claim>{{cite web |author = Leonid Timtchenko| url= http://pubs.aina.ucalgary.ca/arctic/Arctic50-1-29.pdf |title= The Russian Arctic Sectoral Concept: Past And Present| date = June 17, 1996 |accessdate=2011-07-27}}</ref> The first maritime boundary between Russia and Norway, from the [[Varangerfjord]], was signed in 1957. However, tensions resurfaced after both countries made continental shelf claims in the 1960s.<ref name=1957_treaty_norway>{{cite web | author = Thilo Neumann | url= http://www.asil.org/files/2010/insights/insights_101109.pdf | title=Norway and Russia Agree on Maritime Boundary in the Barents Sea and the Arctic Ocean| publisher = The American Society of International Law| date = November 9, 2010 |accessdate=2011-08-27}}</ref> Informal talks began in the 1970s about determining a boundary in the Barents Sea to settle differing claims,<ref name=1957_treaty_norway /> as Russia wanted the boundary to be a line running straight north from the mainland, {{convert|67,000|mi2}} more than what it had. On September 15, 2010, Foreign Ministers [[Jonas Gahr Støre]] and [[Sergei Lavrov]], of Norway and Russia respectively, signed a treaty that effectively divided the disputed territory in half between the two countries, and also agreed to co-manage resources in that region where they overlap national sectors.<ref name="russia-norway-deal">{{cite news | author = Walter Gibbs| url= https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/28/world/europe/28norway.html |title= Russia and Norway Reach Accord on Barents Sea| publisher = ''The New York Times''| date = April 27, 2010 |accessdate=2011-08-09| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110727042857/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/28/world/europe/28norway.html| archivedate= 27 July 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="russia-norway-deal2">{{cite web | url= http://www.eu-norway.org/news1/Treaty-on-maritime-delimitation-and-cooperation-in-the-Barents-Sea-and-the-Arctic-Ocean-signed-today/ |title= Treaty on maritime delimitation and cooperation in the Barents Sea and the Arctic Ocean signed today| publisher = The Norwegian Mission to the EU| date = September 15, 2010 |accessdate=2011-08-09}}</ref><ref name=globemail_arctic>{{cite news | author = Michael Byers | url= https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/opinions/its-time-to-resolve-our-arctic-differences/article1551694/print/ |title= It's time to resolve our Arctic differences |publisher = ''The Globe and Mail''| date = April 30, 2010| accessdate=2011-08-09 | location=Toronto}}</ref> The two countries had already been co-managing [[fishery|fisheries]] in the Barents since the 1978 [[Grey Zone Agreement]], which has been renewed annually since it was signed.<ref name=1957_treaty_norway /><ref name=globemail_arctic />
[[File:Mir front.jpg|210px|thumb|alt=Photograph of a Mir submersible. |[[MIR (submersible)|MIR submersibles]] were used in the Arktika 2007 expedition to the North Pole.]] On March 12, 1997, Russia ratified the [[United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea]] (UNCLOS), which allowed countries to make claims to extended [[continental shelf|continental shelves]].<ref name=UNCLOS>{{cite web | url= https://www.un.org/Depts/los/reference_files/status2010.pdf | publisher = United Nations |title= Status of the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea |accessdate=2011-07-27}}</ref> In accordance with UNCLOS, Russia submitted a claim to an extended [[Continental shelf of Russia|continental shelf]] beyond its 200-mile (320 km) exclusive economic zone on December 20, 2001, to the [[UN Commission on the Limits of the Continental Shelf]] (CLCS). Russia claimed that two underwater mountain chains - the [[Lomonosov Ridge|Lomonosov]] and [[Mendeleev Ridge|Mendeleev]] ridges - within the Russian sector of the Arctic were extensions of the [[Eurasia]]n continent and thus part of the Russian continental shelf. The UN CLCS neither validated nor invalidated the claim but requested Russia to submit additional data to substantiate its claim.<ref name="2001-claim">{{cite web |author = Marc Benitah| url= http://www.asil.org/insights071108.cfm |title= Russia's Claim in the Arctic and the Vexing Issue of Ridges in UNCLOS| publisher = American Society of International Law| date = November 8, 2007 |accessdate=2011-07-27}}</ref> Russia will submit additional data to the CLCS in 2012.<ref name="next-claim-2012">{{cite web | url= http://www.barentsobserver.com/russian-shelf-claim-to-un-in-2012.4940700.html |title= Russian shelf claim to UN in 2012| publisher = ''Barents Observer''| date = July 6, 2011 |accessdate=2011-08-09}}</ref>
In August 2007, a Russian expedition named [[Arktika 2007]], led by [[Artur Chilingarov]], planted a Russian flag on the seabed at the [[North Pole]].<ref name=pole_flag>{{cite news | author = William J. Broad| url= https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/19/world/europe/19arctic.html?adxnnl=1&adxnnlx=1311810481-IXSrMDBjzhfGopGmYcf6tw |title= Russia's Claim Under Polar Ice Irks American | publisher = ''New York Times'' |date = February 19, 2008| accessdate=2011-07-27}}</ref> This was done in the course of scientific research to substantiate Russia's 2001 extended continental shelf claim submission.<ref name=pole_flag /> Rock, mud, water, and plant samples at the seabed were collected and brought back to Russia for scientific study.<ref name=arktika_expedition>{{cite web | author = Mike McDowell, Peter Batson| url= http://www.explorers.org/flag_reports/Mike_McDowell_Flag_42_Report.pdf |title= Last of the Firsts: Diving to the Real North Pole | accessdate=2011-07-27| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110703000041/http://www.explorers.org/flag_reports/Mike_McDowell_Flag_42_Report.pdf| archivedate= 3 July 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The [[Natural Resources Ministry]] of Russia announced that the bottom samples collected from the expedition are similar to those found on continental shelves. Russia is using this to substantiate its claim that the Lomonosov Ridge in its sector is a continuation of the continental shelf that extends from Russia, and that Russia has a legitimate claim to that seabed.<ref name=sample_results>{{cite news | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/7005483.stm |title= Arctic seabed 'belongs to Russia' |publisher = BBC News| date = September 20, 2007 | accessdate=2011-07-27}}</ref> The United States and Canada dismissed the flag planting as purely symbolic and legally meaningless.<ref name=Flag_response>{{cite news |author = Mike Eckel| url= https://www.usatoday.com/tech/science/2007-08-08-russia-arctic-flag_N.htm |title= Russia defends North Pole flag-planting| date = August 8, 2007 |accessdate=2011-07-28 |work=USA Today}}</ref> Russia's Foreign Minister [[Sergey Lavrov]] agreed,<ref name=globemail_arctic /> telling reporters: "The aim of this expedition is not to stake Russia's claim but to show that our shelf reaches to the North Pole."<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/europe/08/02/arctic.sub.reut/index.html?eref=rss_world Russia plants flag on Arctic floor]. CNN News.</ref> He also confirmed that Arctic territory issues "can be tackled solely on the basis of international law, the [[United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea|International Convention on the Law of the Sea]] and in the framework of the mechanisms that have in accordance with it been created for determining the borders of states which have a continental shelf."<ref>{{cite news | first=Sergey | last=Lavrov | title=Transcript of Remarks and Replies to Media Questions by Russian Minister of Foreign Affairs Sergey Lavrov Following His Participation in the 14th Session of the ASEAN Regional Forum on Security, Manila, Philippines, August 2, 2007 | url=http://www.mid.ru/brp_4.nsf/0/432751A496F921E9C325732C004BE119 | publisher=[[Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Russia]] | date=2007-08-03 | accessdate=2007-08-04}}</ref> In another interview Sergey Lavrov said: "I was amazed by my Canadian counterpart’s statement that we are planting flags around. We’re not throwing flags around. We just do what other discoverers did. The purpose of the expedition is not to stake whatever rights of Russia, but to prove that our shelf extends to the North Pole. By the way on the Moon it was the same".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kommersant.com/p792832/Arctic_ocean_bed_causes_upsurge_of_Russia-West_competiton/|title=Cold War Goes North - Kommersant Moscow|publisher=|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref>
Foreign Ministers and other officials representing Canada, Denmark, Norway, Russia, and the United States met in [[Ilulissat|Ilulissat, Greenland]] in May 2008, at the [[Arctic Ocean Conference]] and announced the [[Ilulissat Declaration]]. Among other things the declaration stated that any demarcation issues in the Arctic should be resolved on a bilateral basis between contesting parties.<ref>{{cite news|first= |last= |title=Conference in Ilulissat, Greenland: Landmark political declaration on the future of the Arctic |url=http://www.um.dk/en/servicemenu/News/ConferenceInIlulissatGreenlandLandmarkPoliticalDeclarationOnTheFutureOfTheArctic.htm |publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark |date=2008-05-28 |accessdate=2008-06-06 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080615022625/http://www.um.dk/en/servicemenu/News/ConferenceInIlulissatGreenlandLandmarkPoliticalDeclarationOnTheFutureOfTheArctic.htm |archivedate=2008-06-15 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.um.dk/NR/rdonlyres/BE00B850-D278-4489-A6BE-6AE230415546/0/ArcticOceanConference.pdf |title=The Ilulissat Declaration |date=2008-05-28 |publisher=um.dk |accessdate=2008-06-06}}</ref>
An example of such bilateral agreement was achieved between [[Norway–Russia border#Delimitation agreement|Russia and Norway in 2010]].
==Military== Part of Russia's current Arctic policy includes maintaining a military presence in the region. The [[Russian Northern Fleet]], the largest of the four Russian Navy fleets, is headquartered in [[Severomorsk]], in the Kola Gulf on the Barents Sea.<ref name=SLD_Arctic>{{cite web | author = Dr. Richard Weitz| url= http://www.sldinfo.com/russia%E2%80%99s-recent-arctic-moves-the-non-reluctant-arctic-power/ |title= Russia: The Non-Reluctant Arctic Power |publisher = Second Line of Defense| date = February 12, 2011 | accessdate=2011-11-01}}</ref> The Northern Fleet encompasses two-thirds of Russia's total naval power, and has close to 80 operational ships.<ref name=Laruelle>{{cite book | author = Marlene Laruelle | title = Russia's Arctic Strategies and the Future of the Far North | publisher = M.E. Sharpe, Inc.| place = Armonk, New York | year = 2014 }}</ref> As of 2013, this included approximately 35 submarines, six missile cruisers, and the flagship ''[[Russian battlecruiser Petr Velikiy|Petr Velikiy]]'' (Peter the Great), a nuclear-powered guided missile cruiser.<ref name=Laruelle /> In 2012 the Russian Navy resumed naval patrols of the Northern Sea Route, marked by a 2,000 mile patrol of the Russian Arctic by ten ships led by the ''Petr Velikiy''.<ref name=CSMonitor_resumepatrols>{{cite web | author = Fred Weir | title = Russian Navy returns to Arctic. Permanently. | publisher = The Christian Science Monitor | date = September 16, 2013 | url = http://www.csmonitor.com/World/2013/0916/Russian-Navy-returns-to-Arctic.-Permanently | accessdate = 2014-01-04 }}</ref> The [[Russian Military]] also reportedly announced in June 2008 that it would increase the operational radius of its [[Northern Fleet]] submarines.<ref name=Military_buildup1>{{cite news | author = Adrian Blomfield| url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/russia/2111507/Russia-plans-Arctic-military-build-up.html |title= Russia plans Arctic military build-up |publisher = ''The Telegraph''| date = June 11, 2008 | accessdate=2011-07-27 | location=London}}</ref>
The first [[Nuclear-powered icebreaker|nuclear icebreaker]], the ''[[Lenin (nuclear icebreaker)|Lenin]]'', began operating in the Northern Sea Route in July 1960.<ref name=Brigham_Marine_Transportation>{{cite web | author= Lawson W Brigham| url= http://www.dieselduck.ca/historical/02%20articles/russian.htm | title= Soviet Arctic Marine Transportation |accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref> A total of ten nuclear-powered civilian vessels, including nine [[icebreaker]]s, have been built in Russia. Three of these have been decommissioned, including the ''Lenin''.<ref name=RIA_nuclear_privatization>{{cite web | url= http://arctic.ru/news/2011/10/medvedev-privatizes-russian-icebreaker-fleet | title= Medvedev privatizes Russian icebreaker fleet | publisher= RIA Novosti |date= October 4, 2011|accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref> Besides its six nuclear icebreakers, Russia also has 19 diesel polar icebreakers.<ref name=Icebreaker_Fleet_ArcticSounder>{{cite web | author = Carey Restino| url= http://www.thearcticsounder.com/article/1202icebreaker_fleet_in_us_lags_behind | title= Icebreaker fleet in U.S. lags behind | publisher= The Arctic Sounder |date= January 13, 2012|accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref> Its nuclear icebreaker fleet includes the ''[[50 Let Pobedy]]'' (50 Years of Victory), the largest nuclear icebreaker in the world.<ref name=Laruelle /> There are currently plans to build six more icebreakers, as well as plans to build a $33 billion year-round Arctic port.<ref name=Arctic_seagrab_CSM>{{cite web | author = Fred Weir| url= http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Global-Issues/2011/0814/Russia-s-Arctic-sea-grab | title= Russia's Arctic 'sea grab' | publisher= The Christian Science Monitor |date= August 14, 2011|accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref> On September 28, 2011, President Medvedev lifted the ban on the [[Privatization in Russia|privatization]] of the nuclear icebreaker fleet with decree No. 1256.<ref name=RIA_nuclear_privatization /> This repeal will allow [[Atomflot]], the [[Unitary enterprise|state company]] that owns the fleet, to be at least partially owned by private investors. The government is expected to retain a controlling share in the company.<ref name=VoiceofRussia_privatization>{{cite web | url= http://www.rosatom.ru/wps/wcm/connect/rosatom/rosatomsite.eng/presscentre/nuclear_industry/996f3f80489485519144d5426863e0b2 | title= Russia to privatize its nuclear-powered icebreaker fleet | publisher= The Voice of Russia |date= April 10, 2011|accessdate=2012-03-19}}</ref>
Russia says that it has military units specifically trained for Arctic combat.<ref name=Military_buildup1 /> On October 4, 2010, Russian Navy commander Admiral Vladimir Vysotsky was quoted as saying: "We are observing the penetration of a host of states which . . . are advancing their interests very intensively, in every possible way, in particular China," and that Russia would "not give up a single inch" in the Arctic. <ref>[http://www.uscc.gov/researchpapers/2012/China-and-the-Arctic_Apr2012.pdf FU.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission Staff Research Report] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121002153049/http://www.uscc.gov/researchpapers/2012/China-and-the-Arctic_Apr2012.pdf |date=2012-10-02 }}</ref> Russian Defense Minister Anatoly Serdyukov announced plans on July 16, 2011, for the creation of two brigades that would be stationed in the Arctic.<ref name=Military_buildup2>{{cite web | author = Mia Bennett| url= http://foreignpolicyblogs.com/2011/07/04/russia-arctic-states-solidifying-northern-military-presence/ |title= Russia, Like Other Arctic States, Solidifies Northern Military Presence |publisher = Foreign Policy Association| date = July 4, 2011 | accessdate=2011-07-27}}</ref> Russia's Arctic policy statement, approved by President Medvedev on September 18, 2008, called for the establishment of improved military forces in the Arctic to "ensure military security" in that region, as well as the strengthening of existing [[Border Guard Service of Russia|border guards]] in the area.<ref name=Russian_policy /><ref name=Military_buildup3>{{cite web | url= http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29916834/ns/world_news-europe/t/russia-plans-create-arctic-military-force/ |title= Russia plans to create Arctic military force |publisher = MSNBC| date = March 27, 2009 | accessdate=2011-07-27}}</ref>
==Research== Russia has conducted research in the Arctic for decades. The country is the only one that uses [[North Pole drift ice station|drift stations]]- research facilities seasonally deployed on [[drift ice]]- and also has other research stations in its Arctic zone. The first drift station, [[North Pole-1]], was established on May 21, 1937 by the Soviet Union.<ref name=drift_stations>{{cite web | url= http://www.whoi.edu/beaufortgyre/history/history_drifting.html |title= North Pole Drifting Stations (1930s-1980s) |publisher = Beaufort Gyre Exploration Project | accessdate=2011-07-28| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110720113545/http://www.whoi.edu/beaufortgyre/history/history_drifting.html| archivedate= 20 July 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Russian research has focused on the Arctic seabed, marine life, meteorology, exploration, and natural resources, among other topics. Recent research has also been focusing on studying the Lomonosov Ridge to collect evidence that could strengthen Russian territorial claims to the seabed in that region within the Russian sector of the Arctic.<ref name=drift_stations /><ref name=research1>{{cite web | url= http://blogs.nature.com/news/2010/09/russia_to_boost_arctic_researc.html |title= Russia to boost Arctic research |date = September 23, 2010| accessdate=2011-07-28}}</ref>
[[File:Akademik Fyodorov.png|280px|thumb|alt=Photograph of the ''Akademik Fyodorov'' icebreaker. |The ''[[Akademik Fyodorov]]'' has been actively used with the new ''[[Akademik Tryoshnikov]]'' to conduct research in the Arctic.]] Drifting station [[North Pole-38]] was established in October 2010.<ref name="North_Pole-38">{{cite web | url= http://english.ruvr.ru/2010/12/15/36873740.html |title= North Pole-38 keeps on drifting |publisher = The Voice of Russia| date = December 15, 2010| accessdate=2011-07-28}}</ref> In July 2011 the icebreaker ''Rossiya'' and the research ship ''[[Akademik Fyodorov]]'' began conducting seismic studies north of [[Franz Josef Land]] to find evidence to back up Russia's territorial claims in the Arctic. The ''Akademik Fyodorov'' and the icebreaker ''[[Yamal (icebreaker)|Yamal]]'' went on a similar mission the year before.<ref name=ship_research>{{cite web | url= http://en.rian.ru/russia/20110712/165157148.html |title= Russian research vessel begins Arctic shelf research |publisher = RIA Novosti| date = July 12, 2011| accessdate=2011-07-28}}</ref> The Lena-2011 expedition, a joint Russian-German project headed by [[Jörn Thiede]], left for the [[Laptev Sea]] and the [[Lena River]] in the summer of 2011. It was to study Siberian climate and climate change, as well as gather information about the Russian continental shelf.<ref name="Lena-2011">{{cite web | url= http://english.ruvr.ru/2011/07/21/53532526.html |title= Arctic shelf prospecting in view of global warming |publisher = The Voice of Russia| date = July 21, 2011| accessdate=2011-08-07}}</ref> The head of the expedition, who is also the chairman of the [[European Polar Board|European Arctic Commission]], expressed confidence that Russia will gather the evidence needed to confirm its claim to additional parts of the Arctic shelf.<ref name="Lena-2011(2)">{{cite web | url= http://english.ruvr.ru/2011/07/20/53467482.html |title= Russia likely to achieve Arctic shelf ambitions |publisher = The Voice of Russia| date = July 20, 2011| accessdate=2011-08-07}}</ref>
Current research stations under construction include one on [[Samoylovsky Island]], which should be completed by mid-2012 and will focus on researching shelf zone [[permafrost]],<ref name=samoilovsky_research>{{cite web | url= http://int.rgo.ru/arctic/arctic-news/russia-planning-to-launch-a-new-research-station-in-the-arctic/ |title= Russia planning to launch a new research station in the Arctic |publisher = Russian Geographical Society| date = January 18, 2011| accessdate=2011-07-28}}</ref> and one on the [[Svalbard Islands]], which will be finished in 2013 and will focus on geophysical, hydrological, and geological research.<ref name=svalbard_research>{{cite web | url= http://www.arcticprogress.com/2011/02/russia-plans-to-build-research-center-on-svalbard-by-2014/ |title= Russia Plans to Build Research Center on Svalbard by 2014 |publisher = RIA Novosti| date = February 3, 2011| accessdate=2011-07-28}}</ref>
Over the summer of 2015, Russia built an extremely large military base on the island of [[Alexandra Land]], expanding on an already established airbase called [[Nagurskoye]], on the [[80th parallel north|80th parallel]]. The new complex is made of multiple inter-connected buildings and can house a company of 150 soldiers for up to 18 months without the need of re-supply.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2015/10/21/world/russia-asserts-arctic-clout-opens-large-military-complex-80th-parallel/#.VihEhpVRHs1|title=Russia asserts Arctic clout, opens large military complex on 80th parallel|work=The Japan Times|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref>
==Economy== [[File:Arctic ice.jpg|280px|thumb|alt=Photograph of ice in the Arctic Ocean. |Reduction in Arctic ice due to climate change may open up more economic opportunities in the Arctic.]] Russia's economic interests in the Arctic are based on two things - natural resources and maritime transport.<ref name=geopolitics_economy>{{cite web | author = Katarzyna Zysk| url= http://www.geopoliticsnorth.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2&Itemid=71&limitstart=4 |title= Russia, Norway and the High North - past, present, future - Russian Arctic Strategy |publisher = Norwegian Institute for Defence Studies| date = September 2008 | accessdate=2011-07-28}}</ref> The [[Northern Sea Route]], in use for centuries and officially defined by Russian legislation, is an Arctic [[shipping]] lane that stretches from the Barents Sea to the Bering Strait through Arctic waters. Travel along Northern Sea Route takes only one-third the distance needed to go through the [[Suez Canal]], without as high a risk of [[pirates]].<ref name=Northern_Route_development>{{cite web | url= http://www.barentsobserver.com/future-bases-for-the-northern-sea-route-pointed-out.4863371-16149.html | title=Future bases for the Northern Sea Route pointed out| publisher = ''Barents Observer''| date = December 17, 2010 |accessdate=2011-08-28}}</ref>
The route is currently open for up to eight weeks a year, and studies are predicting that [[climate change]] will lead to further reduction in Arctic ice, which can lead to greater use of the route.<ref name=marine_transport1>{{cite web | url= http://www.arctic.ru/economy-infrastructure/maritime-transport |title= Sea Routes and Marine Transport |publisher = Friends of the Arctic| accessdate=2011-07-28}}</ref><ref name=marine_transport2>{{cite web | url= http://maps.grida.no/go/graphic/northern-sea-route-and-the-northwest-passage-compared-with-currently-used-shipping-routes |title= Northern Sea Routes and the Northwest Passage compared with currently used shipping routes |publisher = United Nations Environment Programme| accessdate=2011-07-28}}</ref> Even when "open" this route is not totally ice free and requires Russian icebreaker and navigational support to ensure safety of passage. Currently {{convert|1.5|e6t}} of goods are transported along the Northern Sea Route every year.<ref name=marine_transport1 /> Traffic through the Route is expected to increase tenfold by 2020, and six tankers have already gone through in 2010.<ref name=Northern_Route_development /> The Russian government estimates that annual cargo traffic could reach 85 million metric tons,<ref name=Platts_NSRShipping>{{cite web | author = Nadia Rodova | title = Russia's Northern Sea Route: Global Implications | publisher = Platts | date = September 26, 2013 | url = http://www.platts.com/news-feature/2013/oil/euro-nsr/index | accessdate = 2014-01-04 }}</ref> and shipping along the Route could account for a quarter of cargo between Europe and Asia by 2030.<ref name=HuffPost_NSRSipping>{{cite web | author = Balazs Koranyi | title = Arctic Shipping to Grow as Warming Opens Northern Sea Route for Longer | publisher = Huffington Post | date = May 29, 2013 | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/29/arctic-shipping-northern-sea-route_n_3351109.html | accessdate = 2014-01-04 }}</ref> However, using the Northern Sea Route extensively will require vast expansion of Russia's current infrastructure in the Arctic, especially [[Transport in Russia#Major sea ports and harbors|ports]] and [[Transport in Russia#Merchant marine|naval vessels]].<ref name=marine_transport1 /> In August 2011 [[Nikolai Patrushev]], Secretary of Russia's Security Council, stated that the poor condition of infrastructure in the Arctic hinders development there, reducing the attractiveness of the region's resources for development.<ref name="ITAR-TASS_August_Conference" /> The infrastructure is worse in the eastern part of Russia, which also contains more resources.<ref name="ITAR-TASS_August_Conference" /> Recent economic sanctions imposed on Russia have additionally weakened the NSR's viability for foreign investors and in 2014 the overall number of voyages across the passage has fallen dramatically from 71 to 53.<ref name="The Maritime Executive">"[http://www.maritime-executive.com/article/sanctions-dull-russias-arctic-shipping-route Sanctions Dull Russia's Arctic Shipping Route]" ''The Maritime Executive'', 22 January 2015. Accessed: 23 January 2015.</ref>
The [[Yamal Peninsula]], home to Russia's biggest natural gas reserves, was connected to the rest of Russia by [[Gazprom]] through the creation of the [[Obskaya–Bovanenkovo Line]], which opened in 2010. This was part of Gazprom's [[Yamal project]] to develop natural gas resources in the Yamal Peninsula.<ref name=Arctic_railway>{{cite web | url= http://www.barentsobserver.com/arctic-railway-launched.4892021.html | title=Arctic railway launched| publisher = ''Barents Observer''| date = March 3, 2011 |accessdate=2011-08-28}}</ref> [[Russian Railways]] plans to connect [[Indiga (village)|Indiga]], which is being considered as a prime location for the construction of a [[deepwater port]], and [[Amderma]], site of the [[Amderma Airport]], to its railway system by 2030.<ref name=Northern_Route_development /> Prime Minister Putin also announced that a year-round port would be constructed on the [[Yamal Peninsula]].<ref name=port_yamal>{{cite web | author = Jeff Davis| url= http://www.canada.com/news/Russia+launches+Arctic+expedition+beefs+military+presence/5060448/story.html |title= Russia launches Arctic expedition, beefs up military presence |publisher = Postmedia News| date = July 6, 2011| accessdate=2011-07-28}}</ref>
But so far, Russia’s concentration on production of oil and gas on the Yamal Peninsula met with huge challenges.<ref name=":0">Staun, Jørgen. [http://www.fak.dk/publikationer/Documents/Russias%20Strategy%20in%20the%20Arctic.pdf “Russia’s Strategy in the Arctic.]” Institute for Strategy, The Royal Danish Defence College. Copenhagen. March 2015. Web. 11 May 2017.</ref> In attempting to extract gas and oil in the Arctic region, Gazprom encounter harsh climate and the long lines of communication. So Gazprom requires large investments with high risk and a long investment horizon and is dependent on the energy prices continuing to be high so that the extraction is profitable. International Energy Agency (IEA) estimates that the majority of the Arctic fields are not profitable if the world market price of oil is below 120 dollars per barrel. At the time of this writing (May 11, 2017), the price of Brent oil has fallen to around 50 dollars per barrel. Meanwhile, since Russian law only allows for the state energy companies Gazprom (mainly gas) and Rosneft (mainly oil) to extract oil and gas from the continental shelf – but since these two firms do not have at their own disposal the necessary technological expertise – they have entered into partnerships with a number of foreign firms.<ref name=":0" />
The Russian Government is also attempting to increase foreign investment in its Arctic resources. In August 2011 [[Rosneft]], a Russian government-operated oil company, signed a deal with [[ExxonMobil]] in which Rosneft received some of Exxon's global oil assets in exchange for the joint development of Russian Arctic resources by both companies.<ref name="Exxon-Rosneft">{{cite news | author = Andrew Kramer |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/31/business/global/exxon-and-rosneft-partner-in-russian-oil-deal.html | title= Exxon Reaches Arctic Oil Deal With Russians |date = August 30, 2011| accessdate=2011-09-05 | work=The New York Times}}</ref> This agreement includes a $3.2 billion [[hydrocarbon exploration]] of the Kara and Black seas (although the Black Sea is not in the Arctic),<ref name=Exxon_joint_exploration>{{cite news | author = Melodie Warner |url= https://www.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20110830-709465.html | title= Exxon Mobil, Rosneft To Jointly Develop Hydrocarbon Resources Globally |publisher = ''The Wall St. Journal''| date = August 30, 2011| accessdate=2011-09-05}}</ref> as well as the joint development of ice-resistant drilling platforms and other Arctic technologies.<ref name="Guardian-deal-research">{{cite web|author=Roger Howard |url=http://www.thepeninsulaqatar.com/business-views/163674-how-arctic-oil-could-break-new-ground.html |title=How Arctic oil could break new ground |publisher=''The Guardian'' |date=September 4, 2011 |accessdate=2011-09-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130802035336/http://www.thepeninsulaqatar.com/business-views/163674-how-arctic-oil-could-break-new-ground.html |archivedate=August 2, 2013 }}</ref> This deal followed a failed attempt at a similar cooperation between Rosneft and [[BP]] in May.<ref name="Exxon-Rosneft" /> [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]] is currently in talks with Rosneft about jointly developing Arctic resources.<ref name=Kara_mapping_Rosneft>{{cite web | author = Atle Staalesen |url= http://www.barentsobserver.com/rosneft-prepares-for-kara-sea-mapping.4955742-16178.html | title= Rosneft prepares for Kara Sea mapping |publisher = ''Barents Observer''| date = September 5, 2011| accessdate=2011-09-05}}</ref>
Russia is the only country in the world planning to use [[Russian floating nuclear power station|floating nuclear power plants]]. The ''[[Akademik Lomonosov]]'', expected to go into operation in 2012, will be one of eight plants that will provide power to Russian coastal cities. There are plans for these plants to also provide power to large [[gas rig]]s in the Arctic Ocean in the future.<ref name=Floating_nuclear_plant1>{{cite news |author = Richard Galpin | url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-11381773 | title=The struggle for Arctic riches| publisher = BBC News| date = September 22, 2010 |accessdate=2011-08-28}}</ref><ref name=Floating_nuclear_plant2>{{cite web |author = Peter Fairley | url= http://spectrum.ieee.org/energywise/energy/nuclear/russia-launches-floating-nuclear-power-plant | title=Russia Launches Floating Nuclear Power Plant| publisher = IEEE Spectrum| date = July 2, 2010 |accessdate=2011-08-28}}</ref> The [[Prirazlomnoye field]], an offshore oilfield in the [[Pechora Sea]] that will include up to 40 wells, is currently under construction and drilling is expected to start in early 2012. It will have the world's first ice-resistant [[oil platform]] and will also be the first offshore Arctic platform.<ref name=Gazprom_Prirazlomnoye>{{cite web|url=http://www.istockanalyst.com/business/news/5379031/gazprom-starts-towing-of-prirazlomnoye-platform-to-field |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130103100728/http://www.istockanalyst.com/business/news/5379031/gazprom-starts-towing-of-prirazlomnoye-platform-to-field |dead-url=yes |archive-date=January 3, 2013 |title=Gazprom starts towing of Prirazlomnoye platform to field |publisher=iStockAnalyst |date=August 25, 2011 |accessdate=2011-08-28 }}</ref><ref name=Prirazlomnoye_TASS>{{cite web|url=http://www.itar-tass.com/c32/212487_print.html |title=Prirazlmonaya sea platform to be delivered to offshore oil field |publisher=ITAR-TASS |date=August 26, 2011 |accessdate=2011-08-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120125063959/http://www.itar-tass.com/c32/212487_print.html |archivedate=2012-01-25 |df= }}</ref>
Russia wants to establish its Arctic possessions as a major resource base by 2020.<ref name=research1 /><ref name=resourcebase_abc>{{cite web | author = Nataliya Vasilyeva |url= http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/wireStory?id=11679368 |title= Russia to Boost Arctic Research Efforts |publisher = ABC News|date = September 20, 2010| accessdate=2011-07-28}}</ref> As climate change makes the Arctic areas more accessible, Russia, along with other countries, is looking to use the Arctic to increase its [[Energy policy of Russia|energy resource production]].<ref name=bbc_resource>{{cite news | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/7967973.stm |title= Russia outlines Arctic force plan |publisher = BBC News|date = March 27, 2009| accessdate=2011-07-28}}</ref> According to the U.S. Geological Survey, there are {{convert|90|Goilbbl|m3}} of [[Petroleum|oil]] and {{convert|1670|e12cuft|m3}} of [[natural gas]] north of the Arctic Circle.<ref name=bbc_resource /><ref name=CNN_economy>{{cite news | author = Marsha Walton |url= http://articles.cnn.com/2009-01-02/tech/arctic.rights.dispute_1_sea-ice-marika-holland-arctic-circle?_s=PM:TECH |title= Countries in tug-of-war over Arctic resources |publisher = CNN|date = January 2, 2009| accessdate=2011-07-28}}</ref> Overall, about 10% of the world's [[Oil reserves|petroleum resources]] are estimated to be in the Arctic. The dominant portion of offshore Arctic hydrocarbon (oil and gas), as reflected in the USGS studies, is located within the current uncontested Exclusive Economic Zones of the five nations bordering the Arctic.<ref name=USGS_economy>{{cite web |url= http://geology.com/usgs/arctic-oil-and-gas-report.shtml |title= USGS Arctic Oil and Gas Report |publisher = U.S. Geological Survey|date = July 2008| accessdate=2011-07-28}}</ref>
In September 2013, Gazprom's oil drilling activities in the Arctic have drawn protests from environmental groups particularly Greenpeace. Greenpeace has opposed oil drilling in the Arctic on the grounds that oil drilling would cause damage to the Arctic ecosystem and that there are no safety plans in place to prevent oil spills.<ref name="Guardian 24 September">{{cite news | author = Shaun Walker |url= https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/sep/24/russia-greenpeace-piracy-oil-rig-protest |title= Russia to charge Greenpeace activists with piracy over oil rig protest |publisher = The Guardian|date = September 24, 2013| accessdate=2013-09-25}}</ref> On September 18, the Greenpeace vessel ''[[MV Arctic Sunrise]]'' staged a protest and attempted to board Gazprom's Prirazlomnaya platform. In response, the [[Russian Coast Guard]] seized control of the ship, and arrested the activists. [[Phil Radford]], executive director of Greenpeace USA, stated that the arrest of the Arctic 30 is the stiffest response that [[Greenpeace]] has encountered from a government since the bombing of the Rainbow Warrior in 1985 by the "action" branch of the French foreign intelligence services, the Direction générale de la sécurité extérieure (DGSE).<ref name="Washington Post">{{cite news | author = Kathy Lally and Will Englund|url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/us-greenpeace-captain-jailed-in-russia/2013/09/27/5e4f6968-2788-11e3-9372-92606241ae9c_story.html |title= U.S. Greenpeace captain jailed in Russia |work = The Washington Post|date=September 27, 2013| accessdate=October 2, 2013}}</ref> Earlier in August 2012, Greenpeace had also staged similar protests against the same oil rig.<ref name=Greenpeace>{{cite web |url= http://www.greenpeace.org/international/en/news/features/Greenpeace-responds-to-allegations-by-Russian-authorities/ |title= Greenpeace International responds to allegations from Russian authorities |publisher = Greenpeace International|date = September 22, 2013| accessdate=2013-09-25}}</ref><ref name="CNA Greenpeace">{{cite news | author = |url= http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/armed-russian-guards/819658.html|title= Armed Russian guards storm Greenpeace vessel in Arctic |publisher = Channel News Asia|date = September 25, 2013|accessdate=2013-09-25}}</ref> The Russian government has intended to charge the Greenpeace activists with piracy, which carries a maximum penalty of fifteen years of imprisonment.<ref name="Guardian 24 September" /> Thirty members of the crew of "Arctic Sunrise" have been detained for 48 hours by authorities in Murmansk. The crew members come from 19 countries. Several members were arrested after having assaulted the Prirazlomnaya drill rig in the Pechora Sea.<ref>Interfax-AVN Moscow Online (English) 0825 GMT 25 September 2013</ref>

'''The Austrian Zoo Organization''' (Österreichische Zoo Organisation - OZO) is the union of the [[Austria]]n, scientifically lead [[zoo]]s, which keep to the international guidelines of the EAZA ([[European Association of Zoos and Aquaria]]).
Member zoos of the OZO fulfill in particular the following criteria:
*High quality in animal husbandry *Participation in kind preservation and nature protection projects *Partaking in research activities for the preservation of the diversity of species
OZO's goals include the implementation of the [[European Union]] zoo directive within Austria, which is designed to ensure the protection of animals in zoos and in the wild.
== Member zoos ==
*[[Tiergarten Schönbrunn]], Vienna *[[Haus des Meeres]], Vienna *[http://www.alpenzoo.at/ Alpine zoo Innsbruck] *[http://www.salzburg-zoo.at/ Salzburger zoo Hellbrunn] *[http://www.herberstein.co.at/ Animal and nature park lock harsh stone] *[http://www.zooschmiding.at/ Zoo Schmiding]
==References== *[http://at.zoo-infos.org/index-en.html at.Zoo-Infos.org] - The Austrian Zoo Database, a non-profit project with information about some 50 zoos, wildlife parks, aquaria, bird parks etc. in Austria (in English).
==External links== {{Official website|http://www.ozo.at/}}

([[United Kingdom|UK]]) |iptv chan 15=Channel 339 | online serv 1 = CNN.com/live | online chan 1 = [http://go.cnn.com/?stream=CNN&sr=watchLiveHPbutton Watch live]
{{small|(U.S. pay-TV subscribers only; requires login from participating television providers to access stream)}} | online serv 2 = [[TVPlayer]] | online chan 2 = [http://www.tvplayer.com/watch/cnninternationaleurope Watch live] (UK only) | online serv 3 = [[DittoTV]] | online chan 3 = [http://www.dittotv.com/livetv/cnni-sa Watch live] (India only) | online serv 4 = FreeInterTV.COM | online chan 4 = [http://www.freeintertv.com/view/id-200 Watch live] (Worldwide) | online serv 5 = [[CNNGo|CNNgo]] Application | online chan 5 = [[Apple TV]] | online serv 6 = [[CNNGo|CNNgo]] Application | online chan 6 = [[Roku]] | online serv 7 = [[IPTV|Internet Protocol television]] | online chan 7 = [[Sling TV]] | online serv 8 = [[IPTV|Internet Protocol television]] | online chan 8 = [[PlayStation Vue]] | online serv 9 = [[iOS]] | online chan 9 = [[CNNGo|CNNgo]] on [[iPad]] }} '''CNN International''' ('''CNNI''', on-air branding simply as '''CNN'''), is an international [[pay television]] channel that is operated by [[CNN]]. CNN International carries news-related programming programming worldwide; it cooperates with parent network [[CNN]]'s national and international news bureaus. Unlike its sister channel, [[CNN]], a US-only subscription service which is mostly broadcast from CNN studios in [[New York City]] and [[Atlanta]], CNN International is carried on a variety of TV platforms across the world, and mostly broadcast from studios outside the US, in [[London]], [[Mumbai]], [[Hong Kong]] and [[Abu Dhabi]]. In some countries, it is available as a [[free-to-air]] network. The current managing director of CNN International is Tony Maddox.[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/sep/04/cnn-international-documentary-bahrain-arab-spring-repression Why didn't CNN's international arm air its own documentary on Bahrain's Arab Spring repression?] CNNi's president, Tony Maddox ==History== ===Early years=== [[Image:CNN-International-Logo.svg|thumb|left|200px|CNN International logo from 1985 to 1995.]] CNN International, in large part a result of [[Ted Turner]]'s globalization ideals, began broadcasting on September 1, 1985, at first primarily broadcasting to American business travelers in hotels. The first studio for CNNI was at CNN's original studio building known as Techwood, home at that time to all of Turner Broadcasting System's channels. Today, it is home to the Turner Studios complex that houses the entertainment channels. Other early studios in Atlanta were tucked away in various corners of the [[CNN Center]], and the newsroom lacked even a [[digital clock]]. The vast majority of the network's programming originally consisted of simulcasts of the two domestic CNN channels ([[CNN|CNN/US]] and [[HLN (TV channel)|Headline News]]). In 1990, however, the amount of news programming produced by CNNI especially for international viewers increased significantly. A new newsroom and studio complex was built in 1994, as CNN decided to compete against [[BBC World Service Television]]'s news programming. CNNI emerged as an internationally oriented news channel, with staff members of various national backgrounds, even though some accusations of a pro-U.S. editorial bias persist. CNN International was awarded the [[Liberty Medal]] on July 4, 1997. Ted Turner, in accepting the medal on behalf of the network, said: "My idea was, we're just going to give people the facts... We didn't have to show liberty and democracy as good, and show socialism or totalitarianism as bad. If we just showed them both the way they were ... clearly everybody's going to choose liberty and democracy."{{cite web|url=http://constitutioncenter.org/libertymedal/recipient_1997.html|title=CNN International - National Constitution Center|website=National Constitution Center – constitutioncenter.org}} ===New international era (1995–2006)=== [[Image:CNN International.png|thumb|left|200px|CNN International logo from February 1, 1995, to December 31, 2005.]] In 1995, creative director Morgan Almeida defined a progressive rebranding strategy, to target CNNI's diverse global market, making the on-air look less overtly American and with a cleaner, simpler "international" aesthetic going forward. The word "International" in the channel's logo was replaced with a globe, and the new branding featured numerous international locations filmed in time-lapse, channel idents created in CGI with Velvet Design in Munich, and a news brand designed with The Attik in New York.{{cite web|url=http://www2.tv-ark.org.uk/news/cnni/idents.html|title=CNN International | Idents|publisher=TVARK|date=|accessdate=2016-08-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304054454/http://www2.tv-ark.org.uk/news/cnni/idents.html#|archive-date=March 4, 2016|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} ===2006–2009 revamp=== [[Image:CNN-globe-logo.png|thumb|left|200px|CNN International logo from January 1, 2006, to September 21, 2009.]] The network undertook another major rebranding effort in 2006 overseen by Mark Wright and London agency Kemistry. The ticker was replaced by a flipper, on-screen graphics were more unified and from October 2007 until August 2008, new studios were progressively rolled out. However, on January 1, 2009, CNN International adopted the "lower-thirds" that CNN/US had introduced a month earlier which were inspired by the clean modern design of the CNNI rebrand efforts. In the U.S., CNNI North America was distributed overnight and on weekends over the [[CNNfn]] financial channel, until that channel's demise in December 2004. It is now available as a standalone, full-time channel, usually as part of high-tier packages of subscription providers including [[Time Warner Cable]], [[AT&T U-Verse]], [[Verizon FiOS]] and [[Cox Communications]]. ===Going beyond borders (2009–2013)=== Throughout January until September 2009, CNN International adapted more programs that became geared towards a primetime European audience with a few titled after CNN International personalities, most notably the interview program Amanpour. On September 21, 2009, the channel launched a new tagline "Go Beyond Borders", along with a new logo, and consolidated its general newscasts (''World News'', ''CNN Today'', ''World News Asia'', ''World News Europe'' and ''Your World Today'') into a single newscast entitled ''World Report''. The slogan "Go Beyond Borders" emphasizes the international perspective that gives the information in this string and the plurality of the audiences. With this tagline, CNN also refers to the various platforms to disseminate their contents. The new image was created by the creativity and marketing department, and agency CNN Tooth & Nail. An important element of the rebrand was a new evening program that adds the broadcast of programs ''Amanpour'' and ''World One''. The makeover of CNN International has subject to a lot of criticism on both the new prime time lineup and the redesigned graphics. On January 11, 2009, in a bid to compete directly with [[Al Jazeera]]'s then English-language international channel, the network launched a new production center: CNN [[Abu Dhabi]], based in the [[United Arab Emirates]]. Then, CNN International adapted half-hour shows in its schedule with a new evening prime program for [[Middle East]] viewers, ''Prism''. In 2010, CNN International launched new programs for its evening lineup in order to improve its schedule. In 2011, programs from CNN U.S. were added to the CNN International schedule, including the talk program ''[[Piers Morgan Live]]'' which was later cancelled and replaced with [[CNN Tonight]] hosted by Don Lemon. [[Image:CNN International 2009.svg|thumb|left|200px|CNN International logo from 2009 to 2014.]] ===This is CNN (2013–present)=== "This is CNN" represents CNN International's rebrand with new sets and output in full 16:9 high definition. The "This is CNN" slogan is also used on its sister network [[CNN/U.S.]] ==Regional and online versions== There are six variants of CNN International: * [[CNN International Asia Pacific]], based in [[Hong Kong SAR]], * [[CNN International Europe/Middle East/Africa]], based in London, [[United Kingdom]] * [[CNN International Latin America]], based in [[Atlanta|Atlanta, Georgia]], U.S. * [[CNN International Middle East]], based in [[Abu Dhabi]], [[United Arab Emirates]] * CNN International North America, based in [[Atlanta, Georgia]], U.S. * [[CNN International South Asia]], based in [[New Delhi]], [[India]] The schedules of the different regional versions no longer differ significantly from each other, but there are still minor variations such as weather updates and show airtimes - notably ''Amanpour'', which also airs at 22.00 HK time in Asia in lieu of the first half-hour of International Desk, and 23.00 CET in Europe in addition to its original airtime. CNN has reported that its broadcast agreement in mainland China includes an arrangement that its signal must pass through a Chinese-controlled satellite. With this method of transmission, Chinese authorities have been able to black out CNNI segments at will. CNN has also said that its broadcasts are not widely available in mainland China, but rather only in certain diplomatic compounds, hotels, and apartment blocks.{{cite news|last=Vause|first=John|title=San Francisco Torch Relay Broadcast|publisher=CNN|date=2008-04-09}} In June 2015, CNN International was made available online in the United States for [[TV Everywhere|CNN/U.S subscribers on participating television providers]] through the CNNgo service.{{cite web|title=CNN International Now Available on CNNgo|url=http://www.adweek.com/tvnewser/cnn-international-now-available-on-cnngo/266213|website=TVNewser|accessdate=2 July 2015}} ==Simulcasts between CNNI and CNN/US== {{Refimprove section|date=May 2018}} Although dramatically scaled down since its early days, CNNI currently (as of mid 2017) draws from the feed of the main CNN channel for all editions of ''[[The Lead with Jake Tapper]]'', ''[[Anderson Cooper 360°]]'', the first hour of Monday through Thursday editions of ''[[CNN Tonight]]'', the first hour of weekday editions of ''[[New Day (TV series)|New Day]]'', ''[[Smerconish]]'', the Sunday edition of ''[[Inside Politics]]'', ''[[State of the Union (TV series)|State of the Union]]'', ''[[Fareed Zakaria GPS]]'', ''[[Reliable Sources]]'' and some ''[[CNN Special Investigations Unit]]'' documentaries. The ticker and timepiece of CNN/US are replaced by those of CNNI, although CNN/US's red logo on a white field is retained in the on-screen graphic (rather than replaced by CNNI's white logo on a red field), signifying CNN/US as the originating source. CNNI also simulcasts CNN/U.S. newscasts whenever major events happen in the United States or around the world. Examples include the [[death and state funeral of Ronald Reagan|death and funeral of Ronald Reagan]], the crash of [[Colgan Air Flight 3407|Continental Airlines Flight 3407]] in the [[Buffalo, New York|Buffalo]] suburb of [[Clarence Center, New York|Clarence Center]], the Hudson River plane landing, the attempted Christmas Day bombing of flight 253 and the death and memorial service of [[Michael Jackson]] as well as scheduled events such as U.S. elections, Presidential inaugurations and the annual [[New Year's Eve Live (CNN program)|New Year's Eve]] ball drop from [[Times Square]]. Likewise, CNN/U.S. occasionally turns to CNNI newscasts, primarily when major international news breaks during overnight hours in the U.S. A notable case was during the [[Funeral of Pope John Paul II|death of Pope John Paul II]] and the aftermath of the [[7 July 2005 London bombings|London Underground bombings of July 7, 2005]]. CNN/U.S. simulcast CNNI coverage of the death of [[Pakistan]]'s former Prime Minister [[Benazir Bhutto]] on the night after her assassination took place. Simulcasts also happened from November 27 to 29, 2008, due to the terror attacks in [[Mumbai, India]], on January 4, 2009, when Israel launched strikes into Gaza, and during the early hours of January 14, 2010, due to the earthquake in Haiti. From 2005 until early 2008, CNNI's ''[[Your World Today]]'' aired on CNN/U.S.{{cite web|author=Home+ |url=http://edition.cnn.com/CNNI/ |title=Breaking News, Latest News and Videos - CNN.com |website=Edition.cnn.com |date=2015-09-01 |accessdate=2016-08-07}} during the 12–1 p.m. ET timeslot. That program was initially pre-empted by ''Issue #1'', a program dealing in the American economic, financial, and housing sectors as part of the lead-up to the [[2008 U.S. presidential election]], and permanently replaced by another hour of ''[[CNN Newsroom]]'' in September 2008. During the [[2008 Atlanta tornado outbreak|Atlanta tornado outbreak in March 2008]], CNN/U.S. and CNNI simulcasted coverage after ''Anderson Cooper 360°'' ended. That coverage ended around 12:40 a.m. EDT and the channels resumed their normal programming. Furthermore, the next day, with storms impending, CNN/U.S. had to move onto CNNI's U.S. news set and weather center to avoid water from possible flooding during the storms. On January 17, 2011, CNN/U.S. dropped its early morning rebroadcasts of ''[[In the Arena|ParkerSpitzer]]'' and ''Anderson Cooper 360°'' during the 4–6 a.m. ET time period, and began to simulcast ''World Business Today'' and ''World One'' from CNNI in those slots. Both newscasts are the only programs broadcast entirely in [[4:3]] fullscreen frames on CNN/U.S.' standard-definition and high-definition feeds (the SD feed of CNN/US switched to a [[widescreen]] [[letterbox]] screen format on January 11, 2011). ''World One'' was dropped from CNN/U.S. just a few months later to allow the addition of an extra hour of ''American Morning'' which has been replaced with ''[[Early Start]]''. As of August 2014, following [[Ferguson unrest|the unrest]] in [[Ferguson, Missouri]], a permanent simulcast of CNNI's block of ''Newsroom'' with [[Rosemary Church]] and [[Errol Barnett]] was added to the late-night lineup of CNN/U.S., serving as a lead-in to ''Early Start''. In late 2015, [[John Vause]] and anchor [[Isha Sesay]] began to anchor a two-hour block of the simulcast from CNN studios in [[Los Angeles]].{{cite web|title=John Vause, Isha Sesay To Anchor CNN International Show From Los Angeles|url=http://www.adweek.com/tvnewser/john-vause-isha-sesay-to-anchor-cnn-international-show-from-los-angeles/268296|website=TVNewser|accessdate=9 December 2015}} ==Programming== ''All news programming is replaced by features, except for the following:'' * ''[[CNN Newsroom (CNNI)|CNN Newsroom]]'' * ''World Sport'' * ''CNNGo'' * ''CNN Talk'' * ''Hala Gorani Tonight'' * ''iReport for CNN'' * ''Winning Post'' - Presented by Aly Vance * ''On China'' – Presented by [[Kristie Lu Stout]] * ''Living Golf'' – Presented by Shane O'Donoghue * ''MainSail'' – Presented by [[Shirley Robertson]] * ''CNN Marketplace Africa'' * ''Inside Africa'' * ''[[Smerconish]]'' * ''[[Inside Politics]]'' * ''[[State of the Union (TV series)|State of the Union]]'' * ''[[Fareed Zakaria GPS]]'' * ''[[Reliable Sources]]'' * ''[[Erin Burnett Outfront]]'' * ''[[CNN Business Traveller]]'' – presented by [[Richard Quest]] * ''[[In 24 Hours]]'' * ''Best Of Quest'' * ''[[Amanpour|Amanpour Weekend]]'' * ''African Voices'' * ''Art of Movement'' * ''[[State of America with Kate Bolduan]]'' * ''The Screening Room'' ===Former programming=== * ''BackStory'' * ''[[Diplomatic License]]'' (1994–2006); debates feature for the United Nations * ''[[NewsNight with Aaron Brown]]'' (2001–2005); talk show; produced by CNN/US * ''[[Late Edition (TV series)|Late Edition]]'' (1993–2009); talk show; produced by CNN/US * ''[[Larry King Live]]'' (1985–2010); talk show; produced by CNN/US * ''[[Piers Morgan Live]]'' (2011–2014); talk show; produced by CNN/US ==High definition== '''CNN International HD''' is the [[high definition television|high definition]] simulcast feed of the channel broadcasting at 1920x[[1080i]], which was launched in September 2012. Prior to 3 June 2013, only programming from CNN US were available natively in HD, while shows made for CNN International were produced in [[4:3]] [[576i]]. In February 2013, the European SD feed of CNN International began broadcasting in widescreen by downscaling the HD feed, which resulted in all 4:3-native programming being broadcast in [[pillarbox]] until the June 3 switchover, finalising on 17 June of the same year, when the switchover was completed. In late 2010, the American CNN channel became available in HD to viewers in [[Japan]] under the name '''CNN HD'''. The CNN U.S. domestic version (both SD and HD) is also available on Greater China-based satellite service [[DishHD]] (subsidiary of [[Dish Network]] in U.S.). On 28 June 2016, CNN International HD was launched for Sky customers in the UK, on channel 506 or 579, making the [[Arirang (TV network)|next news channel]] launch in the 600's, as it is next to the [[God TV|GOD Channel]]. ==Online== CNN debuted its news website CNN.com (initially an experiment known as ''CNN Interactive'') on August 30, 1995. The site attracted growing interest over its first decade and is now one of the most popular news websites in the world. The widespread growth of [[blogs]], [[social media]] and [[user-generated content]] have influenced the site, and blogs in particular have focused CNN's previously scattershot online offerings, most noticeably in the development and launch of [[CNN Pipeline]] in late 2005. In April 2009, CNN.com ranked third place among online global news sites in unique users in the U.S. according to Nielsen/NetRatings; with an increase of 11% over the previous year. CNN Pipeline was the name of a paid subscription service, its corresponding website, and a content delivery client that provided streams of live video from up to four sources (or "pipes"), on-demand access to CNN stories and reports, and optional pop-up "news alerts" to computer users. The installable client was available to users of PCs running [[Microsoft Windows]]. There was also a browser-based "web client" that did not require installation. In July 2007, the service was discontinued and replaced with a free streaming service. The now-defunct topical news program ''[[Judy Woodruff's Inside Politics]]'' was the first CNN program to feature a round-up of blogs in 2005.{{Cite news|url= http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/columnist/mediamix/2005-03-20-media-mix_x.htm|title=It's prime time for blogs on CNN's 'Inside Politics'|date=2005-03-20|publisher=USA Today|last=Johnson|first=Peter|accessdate=2009-01-24}} Blog coverage was expanded when ''[[Inside Politics]]'' was folded into ''[[The Situation Room with Wolf Blitzer|The Situation Room]]''. In 2006, CNN launched CNN Exchange and [[CNN iReport]], initiatives designed to further introduce and centralize the impact of everything from [[blogging]] to [[citizen journalism]] within the CNN brand. CNN iReport which features user-submitted photos and video, has achieved considerable traction, with increasingly professional-looking reports filed by amateur journalists, many still in high school or college. The iReport gained more prominence when observers of the [[Virginia Tech shootings]] sent-in first hand photos of what was going during the shootings.{{cite web|url=http://www.canada.com/reginaleaderpost/news/story.html?id=250570b8-2555-4ac0-8fb7-a0431a321e0d&k=80562|title='Citizen journalist' often there first to snap photos|date=2008-04-12|publisher=Regina Leader-Post|last=Cobb|first=Chris|accessdate=2009-01-24|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080621203445/http://www.canada.com/reginaleaderpost/news/story.html?id=250570b8-2555-4ac0-8fb7-a0431a321e0d&k=80562#|archive-date=June 21, 2008|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} In early 2008, CNN began maintaining a live streaming broadcast available to those who receive CNN at home.{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/video/flashLive/live.html |title=CNN.com Live |website=Edition.cnn.com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-07}} CNN International is broadcast live, as part of the [[RealNetworks]] SuperPass subscription outside the U.S. CNN also offers several [[RSS|RSS feeds]] and [[podcast]]s. On April 18, 2008, CNN.com was targeted by Chinese hackers in retaliation for the channel's coverage on the [[2008 Tibetan unrest]]. CNN reported that they took preventative measures after news broke of the impending attack.{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/TECH/04/18/cnn.websites/ |title=CNN Web site targeted - CNN.com |website=Edition.cnn.com |date=2008-04-18 |accessdate=2016-08-07}}Claburn, Thomas: "[http://www.informationweek.com/government/cybersecurity/cnn-faces-cyberattack-over-tibet-coverage/d/d-id/1066964? CNN Faces Cyberattack Over Tibet Coverage]" [[InformationWeek]], 2008 The company was honored at the 2008 [[Technology & Engineering Emmy Award]]s for development and implementation of an integrated and portable IP-based live, edit and store-and-forward digital newsgathering system. On October 24, 2009 CNN launched a new version of the CNN.com website, revamping it adding a new "sign up" option where users may create their own user name, a new "CNN Pulse" (beta) feature along with a new red color theme.{{Cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/interactive/relaunch/|title=Welcome to the New CNN.com – Interactive tour |publisher=CNN|accessdate=2010-02-20}} However, most of the news archived on the website has been deleted. CNN also has a channel in the popular video-sharing site [[YouTube]], but its videos can only be viewed in the United States, a source of criticism among YouTube users worldwide.{{Cn|date=May 2018}} In April 2010, CNN announced via [[Twitter]] its upcoming food [[blog]] called "Eatocracy," in which it will "cover all news related to food – from recalls to health issues to culture."{{cite web|last=Brion|first=Raphael|title=Eatocracy: CNN Gets in the Food Blog Business|url=http://eater.com/archives/2010/04/13/eatocracy-cnn-gets-in-the-food-blog-business.php|work=Eater.com|date=2010-04-13}} CNN had an [[internet relay chat]] (IRC) network at chat.cnn.com. CNN placed a live chat with [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] on the network in 1998.{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/community/netanyahu/Net1getready.html |title=CNN Community |website=Edition.cnn.com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-07}} CNN also maintains a [[wire service]] known as CNN Wire.{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/intlsyndication/wire.html|title=CNN Syndication Services|website=www.cnn.com}}
