{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Use British English Oxford spelling|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Geoffrey Jones | image = https://goo.gl/images/OlYxC2 | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Birmingham]], United Kingdom | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_co-ordinates = | residence = | nationality = British & American | other_names = | known_for = Professor of Business History at [[Harvard Business School]] | education = | alma mater = [[Corpus Christi College, Cambridge]] | employer = | occupation = Academic | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = | children = Dylan Jones | parents = | relatives = }} '''Geoffrey G. Jones''' is a British-born business historian. He became a US citizen in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Geoffrey-Jones/e/B001HPJVJ8/ |title=Geoffrey Jones: Books, Biography, Blog, Audiobooks, Kindle |accessdate=16 June 2016}}</ref> He is currently Isidor Straus Professor of Business History at the [[Harvard Business School]]. The previous holders of this Chair, which was the first in the world in business history being founded in 1927, included [[Alfred D. Chandler, Jr.]] and [[Thomas K. McCraw]].
Jones's works have concentrated on the historical evolution of globalization, international banking and trading, and [[foreign direct investment]] by multinationals. He has published histories of [[Unilever]], and has more recently written on the history of sustainable business worldwide. In 2017 he published a historical study of green entrepreneurship from the nineteenth century until the present day called ''Profits and Sustainability. A History of Green Entrepreneurship'' (Oxford, 2017)<ref name="Jones2017">{{cite book|author1=Geoffrey Jones|title=Profits and Sustainability. A History of Green Entrepreneurship|year=2017|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-019-870697-7}}</ref>
==Life== Born in [[Birmingham]], Jones attended [[Corpus Christi College, Cambridge|Corpus Christi]], Cambridge.<ref name="JonesKirby1991">{{cite book|author1=Geoffrey Jones|author2=M. W. Kirby|title=Competitiveness and the State: Government and Business in Twentieth-century Britain|year=1991|publisher=Manchester University Press|isbn=978-0-7190-3276-9|page=vii}}</ref> After receiving his Phd, he worked there as a [[research fellow]].<ref name="JonesKirby1991"/> He then became a lecturer in economic history at the [[London School of Economics]] before becoming a professor in business history at the [[University of Reading]].<ref name="JonesKirby1991"/> In 1997 he founded the Centre for International Business History at the University of Reading.[<ref>{{cite web|website=Henley Business School |url=http://www.henley.ac.uk/research/research-centres/the-centre-for-international-business-history |title=The Centre for International Business History |publisher=Henley.ac.uk |accessdate=16 June 2016}}</ref> Jones served twice as President of the [[Association of Business Historians]] (1992–93 and 2000-1), President of the [[European Business History Association]] (1997–1999) and President of the [[Business History Conference]] (2001–2002). Between 1988 and 2003 Jones was the co-editor of the journal ''Business History''.<ref name="Harvey2004">{{cite journal |last= Harvey|first=Charles|year= 2004|title=Tribute to Geoffrey Jones|journal=Business History|volume=46|issue=1|pages=xi–xiii |doi=10.1080/00076790412331270159}}<!--|accessdate=4 June 2010--></ref> In 2002 he moved to Harvard Business School. In 2012 he was appointed Faculty Chair of the Business History Initiative at Harvard Business School. Subsequently, the Business History Initiative developed a project called Creating Emerging Markets, designed to facilitate research and teaching on the business history of emerging markets, which includes interviews with long-time leaders of firms and NGOs in Latin America, South Asia, Turkey and Africa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hbs.edu/businesshistory/emerging-markets/Pages/default.aspx |title=Creating Emerging Markets |website=Business History Initiative |publisher=Harvard Business School}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://hbswk.hbs.edu/item/7702.html |title=Thriving in the Turbulence of Emerging Markets |first1=Geoffrey |last1=Jones |website=Working Knowledge: The Thinking That Leads |publisher=Harvard Business School |date=14 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://hbswk.hbs.edu/item/7508.html |title=Building Histories of Emerging Economies One Interview at a Time |first1=Julia |last1=Hanna |website=Working Knowledge: The Thinking That Leads |publisher=Harvard Business School |date=28 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livemint.com/Companies/LoGGBPJQiLwrAhhBPozQNN/Geoffrey-G-Jones--History-has-its-place-in-business.html |title=History has its place in business |first1=Geoffrey |last1=Jones |website=Live Mint |date= 22 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{YouTube|id=Sra-N-gQp-Y |title=Doing Good By Doing Business – Creating Emerging Markets}}</ref>
Jones holds an honorary Doctorate in Economics and Business Administration from Copenhagen Business School, Denmark, and an honorary Phd from the University of Helsinki, Finland. He is a Fellow of the [[Academy of International Business]] and a Fellow of the [[Royal Historical Society]]. Jones currently serves as the co-editor of the quarterly journal [[Business History Review]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayJournal?jid=BHR |title=Business History Review – Cambridge Journals Online |publisher=Journals.cambridge.org |accessdate=16 June 2016}}</ref>
==Work== Jones initially researched relationships between business and governments. He published historical monographs on the oil industry<ref name="Jones1981">{{cite book|author1=Geoffrey Jones|title=The State and the Emergence of the British Oil Industry|year=1981|publisher=MacMillan Press|isbn=0-333-27595-0}}</ref> and international banking.<ref name="JonesJones1986">{{cite book|author1=Geoffrey Jones|title=Banking and Empire in Iran|year=1986|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=0-521-32322-3}}</ref> From the 1980s, Jones, alongside [[Mark Casson]], was also involved in calling for a more theoretical approach to business history, particularly in the use of [[economic theory]].<ref name="JonesZeitlin2008">{{cite book|author1=Geoffrey Jones|author2=Jonathan Zeitlin|title=The Oxford Handbook of Business History|year=2008|publisher=Oxford Handbooks Online|isbn=978-0-19-926368-4|page=61}}</ref> During this period he wrote historical studies of industries over long time periods, including ''British Multinational Banking 1830-1990'' (Oxford, 1993)<ref name="Jones1993">{{cite book|author1=Geoffrey Jones|title=British Multinational Banking|year=1993|publisher=Clarendon Press|isbn=0-19-820602-X}}</ref> and ''Merchants to Multinationals'' (Oxford, 2000).<ref name="JonesJones2000">{{cite book|author1=Geoffrey Jones|title=Merchants to Multinationals|year=2000|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=0-19-924999-7}}</ref> ''Merchants to Multinationals'' was awarded the Newcomen-Harvard Prize for the best business history book published in the United States between 1998 and 2000, and the Wadsworth Prize for the best work of business history published in Britain in 2000. After moving to Harvard Business School, Jones published books on the history of global business, including ''Multinationals and Global Capitalism'' (Oxford, 2005).<ref name="Jones2005">{{cite book|author1=Geoffrey Jones|title=Multinationals and Global Capitalism|year=2005|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=0-19-927210-7}}</ref> In 2010, Jones published ''Beauty Imagined: A History of the Global Beauty Industry'' (Oxford, 2010).<ref name=Jones2010>{{cite book|author1=Geoffrey Jones|author2=Bee Wilson|title=Beauty Imagined: A History of the Global Beauty Industry|publisher=Oxford University Press|date=2010|isbn=978-0199556496}}</ref> In this book, and elsewhere,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bigthink.com/experts/geoffjones |title=Geoff Jones |publisher=Big Think |accessdate=16 June 2016}}</ref> Jones has sought both to explain the growth of the beauty industry and to explore its impact over the last century on homogenizing beauty ideals worldwide. Recently Jones has focused on the history of green business and [[sustainability]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7zkYeuVoo1M |title=The Importance of Green Business, AIB Conference, Nagoya, 2011 |via=YouTube |date=15 February 2013 |accessdate=16 June 2016}}</ref> and has written on the societal responsibilities of capitalism.<ref>http://www.hbs.edu/faculty/Publication%20Files/14-004_2fbc7e4e-09a2-4c52-9b15-910b43fa0d5b.pdf</ref> In addition to the Creating Emerging Markets project, he has also researched the business history of emerging markets, especially Latin America<ref name="JonesLluch2015">{{cite book|author1=Geoffrey Jones|author2=Andrea Lluch|title=The Impact of Globalization on Argentina and Chile. Business Enterprises and Entrepreneurship|year=2015|publisher=Edward Elgar|isbn=978-1-78347-363-2}}</ref><ref name="JonesSpadafora2017">{{cite journal|author1=Geoffrey Jones|author2=Andrew Spadafora|year= 2017|title=Creating Ecotourism in Costa Rica, 1970-2000|journal=Enterprise & Society |volume=18|issue=1|pages=146–183|doi=10.1017/eso.2016.50}}</ref> and Turkey.<ref name="ColpanJones2016">{{cite journal|author1=Asli Colpan|author2=Geoffrey Jones|year= 2016|title=Business Groups, Entrepreneurship and the Growth of the Koç Group in Turkey |journal=Business History |volume=58|issue=1|pages=69–88|doi=10.1080/00076791.2015.1044521}}</ref> Jones and co-authors have called for the business history of emerging markets to be mainstreamed in the discipline as a whole, and seen as an alternative business history rather than merely adding new settings to explore established core debates <ref name="AustinDavilaJones2018">{{cite journal|author1=Gareth Austin|author2=Carlos Davila|author3=Geoffrey Jones |year= 2017|title=The Alternative Business History: Business in Emerging Markets |journal=Business History Review |volume=91|issue=3|pages=537–569 }}</ref> Jones has encouraged international business scholars to test theories against historical evidence. In 2006 he and [[Tarun Khanna]] published a widely cited article in the [[Journal of International Business Studies]], the premier international business journal, on this issue.<ref name="JonesKhanna2006">{{cite journal|author1=Geoffrey Jones|author2=Tarun Khanna|year= 2006|title=Bringing History (back) to International Business|journal=Journal of International Business Studies|volume=37|issue=4|pages=453–468|doi=10.1057/palgrave.jibs.8400198}}</ref> More recently Jones and Khanna have published on the importance of corporate reputation in emerging markets, employing data from the Creating Emerging Markets project.<ref>{{Citation|last=Harvard Business School|title=Overcoming institutional voids to succeed in emerging markets|date=6 March 2017|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MWq2eSXgdC0|accessdate=7 March 2017}}</ref>
Jones has warned of the risks to the world economy of economic nationalism and [[populism]].<ref name="Brexitisjustthelatestblowtoglobalization">{{cite news|last1=Belsie|first1=Lauren|title=Brexit is just the latest blow to globalization|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Europe/2016/0627/Brexit-is-just-the-latest-blow-to-globalization|accessdate=5 March 2017|work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|date=27 June 2016}}</ref> In 2017, Jones suggested the world economy was undergoing a process of de-globalization.<ref name="mintweareinadeglobalization">{{cite news|last1=Agarwal|first1=Sapna|last2=Raje|first2=Aparna Piramal|title=We are in a deglobalization period: Business historian Geoffrey G. Jones|url=http://www.livemint.com/Companies/tKamdGDvvyCt8Smn39TQMK/We-are-in-a-deglobalization-period-Business-historian-Geoff.html|accessdate=19 February 2017|work=[[Mint (newspaper)|Mint]]|date=18 February 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.hbs.edu/faculty/Pages/profile.aspx?facId=24276 Harvard faculty profile] * [http://www.hbs.edu/businesshistory/emerging-markets/Pages/default.aspx Creating Emerging Markets ]
{{authority control}}

{{unreferenced|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Yugoslavia}} "Ja sam za ples" | image = | caption = | year = 1987 | country = Yugoslavia | artist = [[Sanja Doležal]],
Rajko Dujmić,
Vladimir Kočiš-Zec,
Marinko Colnago,
Nenad Šarić | as = [[Novi fosili]] | with = | language = Serbo-Croatian | languages = | composer = [[Rajko Dujmić]] | lyricist = Stevo Cvikić | conductor = Nikica Kalogjera | place = 4th | points = 92 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1987yu from Diggiloo Thrush] | clip = | prev = Željo moja | prev_link = Željo moja | next = Mangup | next_link = Mangup (song) }} "'''Ja sam za ples'''" (English translation: "I'm up for a dance") was the [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslav]] entry to the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1987]], composed by [[Rajko Dujmić]] and [[Stevo Cvikić]] and sung by [[Novi fosili|Novi Fosili]] in [[Serbo-Croatian language|Serbo-Croatian]]. Performing 21st on the night of the contest (following [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]]'s [[Johnny Logan (singer)|Johnny Logan]] with "[[Hold Me Now (Johnny Logan song)|Hold Me Now]]" and preceding [[Switzerland]]'s [[Carol Rich]] with "[[Moitié, moitié]]"), the song received 92 points, placing 4th in a field of 22. It was succeeded as Yugoslav representative at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1988|1988 contest]] by [[Srebrna Krila]] with "[[Mangup (song)|Mangup]]". {{clear}} {{Yugoslavia in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1987}} [[Category:Croatian songs]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of Yugoslavia]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 1987]] [[Category:1987 songs]] {{Croatia-stub}} {{Yugoslavia-stub}} {{1980s-song-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} The '''KH-11 KENNEN''',<ref name="NRO20160322">{{cite web | title=Develop Acquire Launch Operate (NRO Brochure)|date=22 March 2016 |publisher= NRO| url=http://www.nro.gov/about/nro/NRObrochure.pdf}}</ref><ref name="TSR20120130">{{cite web | title=The geometry of shadows|date=30 January 2012 |first=Dwayne A.|last=Day|publisher= The Space Review| url=http://www.thespacereview.com/article/2013/1}}</ref><ref name="CIA-RDP83M00914R000700040112-1">{{cite web | title=Letter to Honorable Edward P. Boland from William J. Casey proposing visit by permanent select committee members to KENNEN Ground Station, CIA-RDP83M00914R000700040112-1|date=18 January 1982 |first=William J.|last=Casey|publisher= CIA| url=https://www.cia.gov/library/readingroom/document/cia-rdp83m00914r000700040112-1}}</ref><ref name="CIA-RDP74B00415R000100010065-5">{{cite web | title=Briefing of Bill Woodruff and Ralph Preston, Senate and House appropriations committee staff, on KENNEN, CIA-RDP74B00415R000100010065-5|date=15 August 1972 |publisher= CIA| url=https://www.cia.gov/library/readingroom/document/cia-rdp74b00415r000100010065-5}}</ref> renamed '''CRYSTAL''' in 1982<ref name="Richelson">{{cite book|author=Richelson, Jeffrey T.|title=''The Wizards of Langley. Inside the CIA's Directorate of Science and Technology''|publisher=Westview Press, Boulder|year=2001|isbn=0-8133-4059-4}}p.199-200</ref> and according to leaked [[National Reconnaissance Office|NRO]] budget documentation<ref name="FY2013NIP">{{cite web | title=FY 2013 Congressional Budget Justification, Volume 1, National Intelligence Program Summary, Resource Exhibit No. 13|date=February 2012|first=James R.|last=Clapper|publisher= DNI| url=https://www.eff.org/files/2013/11/25/2013-08-30_cryptome_congressional_budget_2013.pdf}}</ref> currently going by the codename of '''Evolved Enhanced CRYSTAL (EECS)'''<ref name="McDowall_NRO">{{cite web | title=NRO Satellites|date=30 August 2013 |publisher= Jonathan McDowall| url=http://planet4589.org/nro/nro.html}}</ref> (but also referenced by the codenames '''1010''',<ref name="Yenne">{{cite book|author=Yenne, Bill|title=''The Encyclopedia of US Spacecraft''|publisher=Exeter Books (A Bison Book), New York|year=1985|isbn=0-671-07580-2}}p.82 '''Key Hole'''</ref> and "'''Key Hole'''"<ref name="Yenne"/>), is a type of [[reconnaissance satellite]] first launched by the American [[National Reconnaissance Office]] in December 1976. Manufactured by [[Lockheed Corporation|Lockheed]] in [[Sunnyvale, California]], the KH-11 was the first American spy satellite to use [[Optoelectronics|electro-optical]] [[digital imaging]], and create a real-time optical observation capability.<ref>{{cite web | title = SOVIET MILITARY CAPABILITIES AND INTENTIONS IN SPACE (NIE 11-1-80) |publisher = Central Intelligence Agency |url = http://www.foia.cia.gov/sites/default/files/document_conversions/89801/DOC_0000284010.pdf |date = 8 June 1980 |accessdate =2 June 2010 |page = 2}}</ref>
[[File:KH-11 KENNEN 01.jpg|thumb|Conceptual drawing based upon Hubble Space Telescope (HST) layout]] [[File:KH-11 KENNEN 02.jpg|thumb|Conceptual drawing based upon Hubble Space Telescope (HST) layout with internal views]]
Later KH-11 satellites have been referred to by outside observers as KH-11B or KH-12, and by the names "Advanced KENNEN", "Improved Crystal" and "Ikon". Official budget documents refer to the latest generation of Electro-Optical satellites as ''Evolved Enhanced CRYSTAL System''.<ref name="FY2013NIP"/> The [[Key Hole]] series was officially discontinued in favor of a random numbering scheme after repeated public references to [[KH-7 Gambit]], [[KH-8 Gambit]]-3, [[KH-9 Hexagon]], and KH-11 satellites.<ref>{{cite book|title=America's Secret Eyes in Space: The U.S. Keyhole Spy Satellite Program|author=Jeffrey T. Richelson| publisher=Harper & Row|year=1990|page=231}}</ref> KH-11 satellites are believed to have been the source of some imagery of [[the Soviet Union]] and China made public in 1997, as well as images of [[Sudan]] and [[Afghanistan]] made public in 1998 that were related to the response to the [[1998 U.S. embassy bombings]].{{cn|date=August 2017}}
== Program history and logistics== The Film Read-Out [[Gambit (satellite)|GAMBIT]] (FROG) served as NRO Program A's competitor to NRO Program B's initial electro-optical imagery (EOI) satellite.<ref>National Reconnaissance Office. GAMBIT and HEXAGON Programmatic Declassification Guidance. 23 June 2011. Released by NRO on 7 March 2012.</ref> After a precursor EOI study with the codeword Zoster, NRO Program B developed an EOI satellite under the initial codeword Zaman, which was replaced by the codeword Kennen in Nov 1971.<ref>{{cite web|title=National Reconnaissance Office Review and Redaction Guide: Version 1.0 2015 Edition|date=2017-06-20|publisher=NRO|url=http://www.nro.gov/Portals/65/documents/foia/declass/ForAll/101917/F-2017-00008.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=KENNEN Memo: Birth of a BYEMAN Codeword|date=1971-11-24|publisher=NRO|url=http://www.nro.gov/Portals/65/documents/foia/declass/ForAll/033017/F-2017-00026.pdf|author=Frederick L. Hofmann}}</ref>
Data is transmitted through a network of [[communications satellite]]s; the [[Satellite Data System]].<ref name="Richelson"/> The initial ground station for the processing of the electro-optical imaging was a secret National Reconnaissance Office facility in [[Area 58]], located in the continental United States according to the NRO,<ref>{{cite web|title=NRO review and redaction guide (2006 ed.)| url=https://fas.org/irp/nro/declass.pdf |publisher=National Reconnaissance Office}}</ref> and more precisely in [[Fort Belvoir]] according to other sources.<ref name="associatepublishers_quasar">{{cite web|title=Quasar (satellite)|url=http://www.associatepublisher.com/e/q/qu/quasar_(satellite).htm|publisher=associatepublisher.com|date=12 March 2010}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
In 1999, NRO selected [[Boeing]] as the prime contractor for the [[Future Imagery Architecture]] (FIA) program, aimed at replacing the KH-11 satellites by a more cost effective constellation of smaller, and also more capable reconnaissance satellites. After the failure of the FIA in 2005, NRO ordered from Lockheed two additional legacy hardware KH-11s.<ref name="DN20090602">{{cite web|url=http://www.defensenews.com/article/20090602/C4ISR02/906020302/Spy-sat-rescue|title=Spy-sat rescue: Obama's proposal to prevent a gap in coverage sparks debate, optimism|publisher=Defense News|first=Ben|last=Iannotta|date=2 June 2009}}</ref> [[USA-224]], the first of these two, was launched in early 2011 two years ahead of the initial schedule estimate.<ref name="NRO20110907">{{cite web| title=10 Who Made a Difference in Space: Bruce Carlson, NRO Director| date=7 September 2011| publisher=Space News / NRO| url=http://www.nro.gov/news/articles/2011/2011-01.pdf| access-date=8 September 2011| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929040832/http://www.nro.gov/news/articles/2011/2011-01.pdf| archive-date=29 September 2011| dead-url=yes| df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In January 2011 [[2012 National Reconnaissance Office space telescope donation to NASA|NRO offered NASA two space optical systems]] with 2.4 m diameter primary mirrors, similar to the Hubble Space Telescope, yet with steerable secondary mirrors and shorter focal length resulting in a wider field of view. These could either be spare hardware from the KH-11 program, or optics from the cancelled FIA program.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/47743440/ns/technology_and_science-space/t/donated-space-telescopes-are-leftover-spy-program-failures |title=Donated space telescopes are leftover spy program failures |publisher=MSNBC |author=Warren Ferster}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title= NRO donates spare telescopes to NASA|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/nro-donates-spare-telescopes-to-nasa-372916/ |publisher=FlightGlobal |author= Zach Rosenberg}}</ref> The satellites were reportedly stored in a clean room facility at [[ITT Exelis]] in Rochester, NY.<ref name="WP20120604">{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/nasa-gets-military-spy-telescopes-for-astronomy/2012/06/04/gJQAsT6UDV_story.html?hpid=z3|title=NASA gets two military spy telescopes for astronomy|publisher=Washington Post|first=Joel|last=Achenbach|date=4 June 2012}}</ref><ref name="NYT20120604">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/05/science/space/repurposed-telescope-may-explore-secrets-of-dark-energy.html?_r=1&pagewanted=all|title=Former Spy Telescope May Explore Secrets of Dark Energy|publisher=New York Times|first=Dennis|last=Overbye|date=4 June 2012}}</ref>
== Design== [[File:HST Lockheed Integration.jpg|thumb|right|Hubble Space Telescope integration at Lockheed]] [[File:KH-11Block3TMAdynamictestunit.png|thumb|right|Dynamical Test Unit of KH-11 (unconfirmed) Three Mirror Assembly]]
===Size and mass=== KH-11s are believed to resemble the [[Hubble Space Telescope]] in size and shape, as the [[satellite]]s were shipped in similar containers. Their length is believed to be 19.5 meters, with a diameter of up to 3 meters.<ref name="Richelson"/><ref name=Wade>{{cite web| author=Mark Wade| date=9 August 2003| url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/kh11.htm| title=KH-11| publisher=Encyclopedia Astronautica| accessdate=23 April 2004| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68ZS4Q10o?url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/kh11.htm| archivedate=20 June 2012| df=dmy-all}}</ref> A [[NASA]] history of the Hubble,<ref>[http://history.msfc.nasa.gov/book/ The Power to Explore], NASA. In particular, [http://history.msfc.nasa.gov/book/chpttwelve.pdf Chapter XII – The Hubble Space Telescope] Chapter 12, p. 483</ref> in discussing the reasons for switching from a 3-meter main mirror to a 2.4-meter design, states: "In addition, changing to a 2.4-meter mirror would lessen fabrication costs by using manufacturing technologies developed for military spy satellites."
Different versions of the KH-11 vary in mass. Early KH-11s were reported to be comparable in mass to the [[KH-9 Hexagon]]<ref name=NYTimes19850113>{{cite web| first=James|last=Bamford| date=13 January 1985 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/01/13/magazine/america-s-supersecret-eyes-in-space.html| title=America's super secret eyes in space| publisher=NY Times}}</ref>, i.e. about 12,000 kg. Later blocks are believed to have a mass of around 19,600 kg.<ref name="Richelson"/>
===Propulsion module===
It has been reported that KH-11s are equipped with a [[Hydrazine]] powered propulsion system for orbital adjustments. In order to increase the orbital lifetime of KH-11s, plans existed for refuelling the propulsion module during service visits by the [[Space Shuttle]].<ref name=NYTimes19850113/> It has been speculated that the propulsion module is related to Lockheed's [[Satellite Support Bus]] (SSB), which had been derived from the [[KH-9_Hexagon#Development|Satellite Control Section]] (SCS) developed by Lockheed for KH-9.<ref name=TheSpaceReview20110207>{{cite web| first=Dwayne A.|last=Day| date=7 February 2011 |url=http://www.thespacereview.com/article/1774/2| title=The flight of the Big Bird (part 2)| publisher=The Space Review}}</ref>
===Optical Telescope Assembly===
A [[CIA]] history states that the primary mirror on the first KH-11s measured 2.34 meters, but sizes increased in later versions.<ref name="Richelson"/> NRO led the development of a computer controlled mirror polishing technique, which was subsequently also used for the polishing of the primary mirror of the Hubble Space Telescope.<ref name=GJTenet20000927>{{cite web| first=George J.|last=Tenet| date=27 September 2000 |url=https://www.cia.gov/news-information/speeches-testimony/2000/dci_speech_09272000_gala.html| title=DCI Remarks at the NRO 40th Anniversary Gala| publisher=CIA}}</ref>
Later satellites had larger mirrors, with a diameter of around 2.9–3.1 m.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/space/systems/kh-12.htm|title=KH-12 Improved Crystal|author=Charles P. Vick| publisher=GlobalSecurity.org|date=25 April 2007}}</ref> ''[[Jane's Defence Weekly]]'' indicates that the secondary mirror in the [[Cassegrain reflector|Cassegrain]] [[reflecting telescope]] system could be moved, allowing images to be taken from angles unusual for a satellite. Also, there are indications that the satellite can take images every five seconds.
===Imaging sensors===
KH-11 Block II might have been the first reconnaissance satellite equipped for imaging with a {{nowrap|800 x 800 pixels}} [[charge-coupled device]] (CCD).<ref>[http://www.globalsecurity.org/space/systems/kh-11.htm globalsecurity.org – KH-11 KENNAN], 24 April 2007</ref> Later block satellites may include [[signals intelligence]] capabilities and greater sensitivity in broader [[electromagnetic spectrum|light spectrum]]s (probably into [[infrared]]).<ref name="CBOPublication528">{{cite web | title=U.S. Costs of Verification and Compliance Under Pending Arms Treaties (CBO Publication #528) |year=September 1990 |publisher= CONGRESSIONAL BUDGET OFFICE, CONGRESS OF THE UNITED STATES | url=http://www.cbo.gov/ftpdocs/77xx/doc7775/90-CBO-043.pdf}}</ref>
===Communications===
Communication to and data downloads from KH-11 satellites are routed through a constellation of communication relay satellites in higher orbits. The initial communications relay payload is believed to have operated at a frequency of 60 GHz, as radio emission at this frequency is blocked by Earth's atmosphere, and thus not detectable from the ground. Launch of the initial two [[Satellite Data System|Satellite Data System satellites]] occurred in June and August 1976, i.e. ahead of the first launch of a KH-11 satellite in late 1976.<ref name=TheSpaceReview20180267>{{cite web| first=Dwayne A.|last=Day| date=26 February 2018 |url=http://www.thespacereview.com/article/3440/1| title=Shadow dancing: the Satellite Data System| publisher=The Space Review}}</ref>
===Resolution and ground sample distance===
A perfect 2.4-meter [[mirror]] observing in the visual (i.e. at a wavelength of 500 nm) has a [[Angular_resolution#Single_telescope|diffraction limited resolution]] of around 0.05 arcsec, which from an orbital altitude of 250 km corresponds to a [[ground sample distance]] of 0.06 m (6 cm, 2.4 inches). [[Astronomical seeing|Operational resolution]] should be worse due to effects of the [[Fried parameter|atmospheric turbulence]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Fried|first=D. L.|title=Optical Resolution Through a Randomly Inhomogeneous Medium for Very Long and Very Short Exposures|journal=Journal of the Optical Society of America|date=October 1966|volume=56|issue=10|pages=1372–1379|doi=10.1364/JOSA.56.001372|url=http://www.opticsinfobase.org/abstract.cfm?id=53167|bibcode=1966JOSA...56.1372F}}</ref> Astronomer [[Clifford Stoll]] estimates that such a telescope could resolve up to "a couple inches. Not quite good enough to recognize a face".<ref name="stoll1989">{{cite book | title=The Cuckoo's Egg | publisher=Doubleday | author=Stoll, Clifford | year=1989 | isbn=978-0-307-81942-0 | authorlink=Clifford Stoll | pages=320–321}}</ref>
When NRO donated two Optical Telescope Assemblies (OTA) to NASA in January 2011, they were suspected to be KH-11 series "extra hardware", but were later attributed to the [[Future Imaging Architecture]] program. The donated OTAs feature a [[three-mirror anastigmat]] (TMA) optical design, without the tertiary mirror. The f/1.2 primary has a diameter of 2.4 m, and is refocused by the secondary to give an overall f/8 focal ratio, making the optical telescope assembly shorter than that of HST. With the addition of the tertiary mirror, this will produce a much wider field than Hubble's 2-mirror f/24 Ritchey–Chrétien optical design, making it a potentially ideal observatory for [[Dark Energy]] or other astrophysics surveys. The secondary mirror is mounted on a [[Stewart platform|hexapod]] to increase the side-viewing and ground scanning ability for the originally intended reconnaissance mission.<ref name="WP20120604"/><ref name="NYT20120604"/><ref name="Dressler20120604">{{cite web|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/assets/pdf/A219029465.PDF|title=The NRO-1 2.4-m Telescope|publisher=The National Academies|first=Alan|last=Dressler|date=4 June 2012}}</ref>
=== KH-11 generations=== Five generations of U.S. electro-optical reconnaissance have been identified:<ref name="sfr20090622">{{cite web|url=http://www.thespacereview.com/article/1400/1|title=Gum in the Keyhole|publisher=The Space Review|first=Dwayne|last=Day|date=22 June 2009}}</ref><ref name="nsf20110120">{{cite web|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2011/01/live-delta-iv-heavy-launch-nro-l-49/|title=Delta IV Heavy launches on debut West Coast launch with NRO L-49|publisher=nasaspaceflight.com|first=William|last=Graham|accessdate=21 January 2011|date=20 January 2011}}</ref>
==== Block I==== Block I refers to the original KH-11 satellite, of which five were launched between 19 December 1976 and 17 November 1982.
==== Block II==== The three Block II satellites are in the open literature referred to as KH-11B, the alleged ''DRAGON'' codename, or ''Crystal'', and are believed to be capable of taking infrared images in addition to optical observations.<ref name="GS20070424"/> The first or second Block II satellite was lost in a launch failure.<ref name="nsf20110120"/>
==== Block III==== Four Block III satellites, commonly called KH-12 or ''Improved Crystal'' were launched between November 1992 and October 2001. The name "Improved Crystal" refers to the "Improved Metric CRYSTAL System" (IMCS), which adds reference markings for accurate mapping to images obtained by the satellite.<ref>{{cite web | title=National Security Archive Electronic Briefing Book No. 13: U.S. Satellite Imagery, 1960–1999|date=14 April 1999 |first=Jeffrey T.|last=Richelson|publisher= National Security Archive| url=http://www.gwu.edu/%7Ensarchiv/NSAEBB/NSAEBB13/index.html}}</ref> Another improvement was an eightfold increase in the download rate compared to earlier models to facilitate improved real-time access and increased area coverage.<ref>{{cite web| title=KH-11 Recons Modified| date=9 October 1995| publisher=Aviation Week| url=http://intellit.muskingum.edu/alpha_folder/a_folder/aw%26st.html| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100626010638/http://intellit.muskingum.edu/alpha_folder/A_folder/aw%26st.html| archivedate=26 June 2010| df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==== Block IV ==== Three electro-optical satellites launched in October 2005, January 2011, and August 2013 are attributed to Block IV.
==== Block V ==== A new generation of clandestine communications satellites launched to inclined geosynchronous orbits have let to speculations that these are in support of Block V electro-optical satellites scheduled for launch in late 2018 (NROL-71) and 2020 (NROL-82) <ref>{{cite web | title=Spy satellite infrastructure supported by successful Atlas 5 rocket launch|date=28 July 2016 |first=Justin|last=Ray|publisher=Spaceflight Now| url=https://spaceflightnow.com/2016/07/28/spy-satellite-infrastructure-supported-by-atlas-5-rocket-launch/}}</ref>.
==Derivatives== The ''[[Misty (satellite)|Misty]]'' satellite is believed to have been derived from the KH-11, but modified to make it [[Stealth technology|invisible to radar]], and hard to detect visually. The first Misty satellite, [[USA-53]], was released by the {{OV|104}} on mission [[STS-36]]. The [[USA-144]] satellite, launched on 22 May 1999 by a [[Titan IV]]B from [[Vandenberg Air Force Base]] may have been a second Misty satellite,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.astronautix.com/craft/misty.htm |title=Encyclopedia Astronautica – Misty |publisher=Astronautix.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129035529/http://astronautix.com/craft/misty.htm |archivedate=29 November 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> or an [[Enhanced Imaging System]] spacecraft. The satellites are sometimes identified as KH-12s.
==Compromise== [[File:Janeskh11leakedphoto.jpg|right|thumb| KH-11 image of the [[Black Sea Shipyard|construction]] of a Kiev-class aircraft carrier, as published by Jane's in 1984.]]
In 1978, a young CIA employee named [[William Kampiles]] was accused of selling a KH-11 System Technical Manual describing design and operation to the Soviets. Kampiles was convicted of espionage and initially sentenced to 40 years in prison.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/14.02/spy_pr.html | title=I Spy | publisher=Wired | author=Patrick Radden Keefe |date=February 2006}}</ref> Later, this term was reduced, and after serving 18 years, Kampiles was released in 1996.<ref name="jonathonpollard_kampiles">{{cite web | title = The Kampiles Case | work = JonathanPollard.org | url = http://www.jonathanpollard.org/kampiles.htm | accessdate =30 December 2010}}</ref><ref name="bop_kampiles">{{cite web | title = Record of William Peter Kampiles | work = Inmate Locator | publisher = Federal Bureau of Prisons | url = http://www.bop.gov/iloc2/InmateFinderServlet?Transaction=NameSearch&needingMoreList=false&FirstName=william&Middle=&LastName=Kampiles&Race=U&Sex=M&Age=&x=36&y=17 | accessdate =30 December 2010}}</ref>
In 1984 [[Samuel Loring Morison]], an intelligence analyst at the Naval Intelligence Support Center, forwarded three classified images taken by KH-11 to the publication ''[[Jane's Fighting Ships]]''. In 1985, Morison was convicted in Federal Court on two counts of espionage and two counts of theft of government property, and was sentenced to two years in prison.<ref>''New York Times'': [https://www.nytimes.com/1985/12/08/weekinreview/the-nation-two-years-for-morison.html Michael Wright and Caroline Rand Herron, "Two Years for Morison," 8 December 1985]. Retrieved 11 March 2011</ref> He was pardoned by President [[Bill Clinton|Clinton]] in 2001.<ref name=lewis>''New York Times'': [https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0B17FC3E5F0C708CDDAA0894D9404482& [[Anthony Lewis]], "Abroad at Home; The Pardons in Perspective," 3 March 2001]. Retrieved 11 March 2011</ref>
==KH-11 missions== [[File:KH-11 Keyhole constellation, September 2013.png|thumb|All KH-11 Keyhole satellites on orbit, orbital constellation status of September 2013]]
Nine KH-11 satellites were launched between 1976 and 1990 aboard [[Titan (rocket family)|Titan]]-3D and -34D rockets, with one launch failure. For the following five satellite launches between 1992 and 2005, a [[Titan IV]] launch vehicle was used. The two most recent launches in 2011 and 2013 were carried out by [[Delta IV#Delta IV Heavy|Delta IV Heavy]] rockets. The KH-11 replaced the [[KH-9]] film return satellite, among others, the last of which was lost in a liftoff explosion in 1986.
KH-11 satellites are in either of two standard planes in [[Sun-synchronous orbit]]s. As shadows help to discern ground features, satellites in a standard plane east of a noon/midnight orbit observe the ground at local afternoon hours, while satellites in a western plane observe the ground at local morning hours.<ref name="GS20070425">{{cite web| url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/space/systems/kh-12.htm| title=IMPROVED – ADVANCED CRYSTAL / IKON / 'KH-12'|first=Charles P.|last=Vick|publisher=globalsecurity.org|date=25 April 2007}}</ref><ref name="satobs20090713">{{cite web| url=http://satobs.org/seesat_ref/misc/KH-11_lifetime.pdf| title=KH-11 Lifetime|first=Ted|last=Molczan|publisher=satobs.org|date=13 July 2009}}</ref><ref name="SatTrackCam1">{{cite web| url=http://sattrackcam.blogspot.nl/2013/09/the-orbit-of-usa-245-and-current-kh-11.html| title=The orbit of USA 245 and the current KH-11 constellation |first=Marco |last=Langbroek|publisher=SatTrackCam Leiden|date=9 September 2013}}</ref> Historically launches have therefore been timed to occur either about two hours before or one hour after local noon (or midnight), respectively.<ref name="nsf20110120"/> The orbits are such that ground-tracks repeat after a certain number of days, currently each four days for the primary satellites in the East and West orbital plane.<ref name="SatTrackCam2">{{cite web| url=http://sattrackcam.blogspot.nl/2013/09/on-usa-245-and-usa-129-and-future-of.html| title=On USA 245 and USA 129, and the future of the Keyhole constellation: an afterthought to my previous post |first=Marco |last=Langbroek|publisher=SatTrackCam Leiden|date=13 September 2013}}</ref>
The constellation consists of two primary and two secondary satellites (one primary and one secondary per plane). The orbital planes of the two primary satellites in the East and West plane are separated by 48 to 50 degrees. The orbital plane of the secondary satellite in the East plane is located 20 degrees to the east of the primary satellite, while the orbital plane of the secondary satellite in the West plane is located 10 degrees to the west of the primary satellite.<ref name="SatTrackCam2"/><ref name="SatTrackCam3">{{cite web| url=http://sattrackcam.blogspot.nl/2013/09/past-and-future-of-kh-11-keyholeevolved.html| title=Past and future of the KH-11 Keyhole/Evolved Enhanced CRYSTAL constellation (part 3) |first=Marco |last=Langbroek|publisher=SatTrackCam Leiden|date=16 September 2013}}</ref>

[[File:KH12 USA129 satellite.jpg|thumb|280px|right|A bright pass of USA-129, a Block III satellite]]
KH-11 satellites require periodic reboosts to counter [[Drag (physics)|atmospheric drag]], or to adjust their ground track to surveillance requirements. Based on data collected by amateur observers, the following orbital characteristics of OPS 5705 were calculated by amateur skywatcher [[Ted Molczan]].<ref name="MSNBC201008">{{cite web|url=https://fas.org/spp/military/program/imint/tm120402.html|title=Examples of other 'fake space' claims by governments?|publisher=fas.org|first=Ted|last=Molczan|date=4 December 2002}}</ref>
On 4 September 2010, amateur astrophotographer [[Ralf Vandebergh]] took some pictures of a KH-11 (USA-129) satellite from the ground. The pictures, despite being taken with a 10-inch aperture telescope from a range of 336 kilometers, show major details such as dishes and solar panels, as well as some elements whose function is not known.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spacesafetymagazine.com/2013/09/26/view-keyhole-satellite/|title=Never Before Seen View of a Keyhole Satellites?|work=Space Safety Magazine |date=2013-09-26|accessdate=2013-10-08}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! OPS 5705<br/>Time period ! [[Periapsis]]<br/>([[Above mean sea level|AMSL]]) ! [[Apoapsis]]<br/>([[Above mean sea level|AMSL]]) ! Apogee at end of period<br>([[Above mean sea level|AMSL]]) |- | 19 December 1976 – 23 December | {{convert|253|km|abbr=on}} | {{convert|541|km|abbr=on}} | {{convert|541|km|abbr=on}} |- | 23 December 1976 – 27 March 1977 | {{convert|348|km|abbr=on}} | {{convert|541|km|abbr=on}} | {{convert|537|km|abbr=on}} |- | 27 March 1977 – 19 August | {{convert|270|km|abbr=on}} | {{convert|537|km|abbr=on}} | {{convert|476|km|abbr=on}} |- | 19 August 1977 – 1978 January | {{convert|270|km|abbr=on}} | {{convert|528|km|abbr=on}} | {{convert|454|km|abbr=on}} |- | 1978 January – 28 January 1979 | {{convert|263|km|abbr=on}} | {{convert|534|km|abbr=on}} | Deorbited |}
==Cost== Estimated unit costs, including launch and in 1990 dollars, range from US$1.25 to 1.75 billion (inflation adjusted US${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|1.25|1990|r=2}}}} to {{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|1.75|1990|r=2}}}} billion in {{Inflation-year|US}}).<ref name="CBOPublication528"/>
According to Senator [[Kit Bond]] initial budget estimates for each of the two legacy KH-11 satellites ordered from Lockheed in 2005 were higher than for the latest [[Nimitz class aircraft carrier|''Nimitz''-class aircraft carrier]] (CVN-77)<ref name="DN20090602"/> with its projected procurement cost of US$6.35 billion as of May 2005.<ref name="NHC20050525">{{cite web|url=http://www.history.navy.mil/library/online/navycvn21.htm |title=Navy CVN-21 Aircraft Carrier Program: Background and Issues for Congress |publisher=Naval Historical Center |first=Ronald |last=O'Rourke |date=25 May 2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061201055019/http://www.history.navy.mil/library/online/navycvn21.htm |archivedate= 1 December 2006 |df= }}</ref> In 2011, after the launch of USA-224, DNRO [[Bruce A. Carlson|Bruce Carlson]] announced that the procurement cost for the satellite had been US$2 billion under the initial budget estimate, which would put it at about US$4.4 billion (inflation adjusted US${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|4.4|2011|r=2}}}} billion in {{Inflation-year|US}}).<ref name="NRO20110907"/>
In April 2014, the NRO assigned a "(...) worth more than $5 billion (...)" to the final two legacy KH-11 satellites.<ref name="NROPR201402">{{cite web |url=http://www.nro.gov/news/press/2014/02-14.pdf|title=Dr. Darrell Zimbelman Receives 2014 Charyk Award, Release # 02-14|publisher=National Reconnaissance Office|date=8 April 2014}}</ref>
==Image gallery== <gallery perrow=4> File:KH-BOMBER-IMAGE.jpg|KH-11 image of a [[Xian H-6]] jet bomber operated by China. File:KH-11-best-SHIPYARD.jpg|2nd KH-11 image of the construction of a Kiev-class aircraft carrier leaked to Jane's in 1984 File:SP38G5.jpg|U.S. reconnaissance satellite image of the [[Al-Shifa pharmaceutical factory]], attributed to KH-11 File:Zhawar Kili Al-Badr Camp.jpg|KH-11 image of the [[Zhawar Kili]] camp in Afghanistan </gallery>

4620 [[Differdange]] | circulation = | sister newspapers = | ISSN = | oclc = | website = [http://www.lessentiel.lu/ www.lessentiel.lu] }} '''''L'essentiel''''' is a [[francophone]], [[free daily newspaper]] in [[Luxembourg]]. ==History and profile== ''L'essentiel'' was established in 2007{{cite web|title=Media|url=http://www.luxembourg.public.lu/catalogue/medias/ap-medias/AP-Medias-2013-EN.pdf|publisher=Grand Duchy of Luxembourg|accessdate=14 November 2014}} and is published in French.{{cite web|title=Media|url=http://vienne.mae.lu/en/Information-about-Luxembourg/Media|work=Embassy of Luxembourg in Vienna|accessdate=2 February 2014}} It is published by Edita SA: a joint venture between [[Switzerland]]'s [[Tamedia]] and Luxembourg-based [[Editpress]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.lessentiel.lu/ L'essentiel official website] {{fr}} * [http://www.lessentiel.lu/de// L'essentiel official website] (German) {{Newspapers in Luxembourg}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Essentiel}} [[Category:Daily newspapers published in Luxembourg]] [[Category:Publications established in 2007]] [[Category:2007 establishments in Luxembourg]] [[Category:French-language newspapers published in Luxembourg]] [[Category:Free daily newspapers]] {{Luxembourg-newspaper-stub}}

{{Refimprove|date=March 2008}} [[File:Besichtigung Brauerei (9741465390).jpg|thumbnail|Beer filling line]]
'''Laško Brewery''' ({{lang-sl|Pivovarna Laško}}) is the largest [[brewery]] in [[Slovenia]]. It is named after the town of [[Laško]], where it is located.
[[File:Lasko, slovenia.jpg|thumb|Laško truck near the entrance of town]] The brewery was founded in 1825 by [[Franz Geyer]], a [[gingerbread]] baker and [[mead]] producer. After [[World War II]] ended in 1945, Laško was the fifth-largest in [[Yugoslavia]], and by 1991 it was the largest among 28 Yugoslav breweries. It lost much of the Yugoslav market in 1991 after Slovenia declared independence and the resulting [[Ten-Day War]], although sales rebounded during the 1990s.
In 2016 Laško and Union were formally merged into ''Pivovarna Laško Union'' under the Owner Heineken.<ref>[http://www.sloveniatimes.com/lasko-and-union-formally-merged "Laško and Union formally merged"], retrieved 14 June 2017.</ref>
==Brands== ;Laško<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lasko.eu/|title=Pivovarna Laško|website=www.lasko.eu}}</ref> *Zlatorog *Eliksir *Dark *Light *Jubilejnik *Club *Trim *Malt *Radler [[File:Pivo Laško icecold.jpg|thumb|A Laško beer in an icecold mug]]
;Bandidos<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bandidos.eu/index_si.html|title=Bandidos|publisher=}}</ref> *Cuba Libre *Ice *Tequila *Sun
;iC Cider<ref> [http://www.ic-cider.com/ iC Cider]</ref>
;Oda water<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oda.si/|title=Oda|first=Design: Atelje Balant, www.a-balant.com / Interaction: Neostudio,|last=www.neostudio.si|website=www.oda.si}}</ref>
Laško Group also owns a few country`s most known beverage companies, including:
*[[Pivovarna Union]] d.d. - the country`s second largest brewery with headquarters in the capital city - [[Ljubljana]]. *[[Radenska]] d.d. - the country`s largest water manufacturer, which produces the world famous mineral water - Radenska. Company's headquarters is in city of [[Radenci]] *[[Vital Mestinje]] d.o.o. - soft drinks manufacturer. Company's headquarters is in city of [[Podplat]]
The Group has also some other subsidiaries, but owns less than 50% of the companies: [[Mercator (retail)|Mercator]], [[Delo]], [[Slovita]], [[Jadranska pivovara]], [[RA&LA]] and [[Firma Del]].
The brewery participates in the annual summertime [[Festival of Beer & Flowers]] (''Pivo-Cvetje'') in Laško, one of the most popular events for tourists in the country.

'''Mantri''' ({{lang-sa|मन्त्री}}) is a word of [[Sanskrit]] origin (meaning [[List of types of spiritual teachers|sage]], i.e. the "person who thinks and says" in that language, cf. [[Mantra]]), and it is used for a variety of public offices, from fairly humble to ministerial in rank. The term was used in various Asian cultures and eventually was used by early European traders. The term also forms part of a number of compounds. It is the root of the English word [[Mandarin (bureaucrat)|mandarin]], for a bureaucrat of the Chinese empire (though the word was never used by the Chinese themselves).
==South Asia==
===Bangladesh=== *Mantri is used synonymously with Minister in Bengali language. *Pradhan-Mantri: Prime Minister *Mantri: Minister *Prati-Mantri: Minister of state *Upa-Mantri: Deputy minister *Mantri-Sabha: Cabinet *Mantri-Parishad: Council of Ministers
===India=== *The word Mantri is often used to mean 'Minister' in Hindi as well as in many other Indian languages, several variations such as Mukhyamantri (chief minister) and Pradhanmantri (prime minister) are also used. *In [[Satara (city)|Satara]], where the [[Peshwa]] (formally First Minister) took over political power from the nominal Monarch: Mantri was used as synonymous Sanskrit version of [[Waqnis]] (Fourth Minister) *Mantri is a surname used by [[Maheshwari]] caste, part of [[Marwari people|Marwadi]] community. *Mantri is a surname used by [[Yadav]] People in North Districts of Tamil Nadu. *Mantri is a surname used by Niyogi Brahmins in Andhra Pradesh. *Mantri is also the brand name of a real estate company based in Bangalore, founded by Sushil Mantri.
===Nepal=== *Mantri: Minister of State *Pradhan Mantri: Prime Minister (compare [[Pradhan]])
==South East Asia== ===Brunei=== '''Mentri''' (or Mantri): ministerial rank below [[vizier]].
===Cambodia=== */nieyʊək roat~roattʰaʔ mʊəntrəy/ (នាយករដ្ឋមន្ត្រី; nāyaka raṭṭha mantrī): Prime Minister<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sealang.net/api/api.pl?query=%E1%9E%93%E1%9E%B6%E1%9E%99%E1%9E%80%E1%9E%9A%E1%9E%8A%E1%9F%92%E1%9E%8B%E1%9E%98%E1%9E%93%E1%9F%92%E1%9E%8F%E1%9F%92%E1%9E%9A%E1%9E%B8&service=dictionary|title=SEAlang Dictionary|website=sealang.net|language=en|access-date=2018-06-13}}</ref> */ʔuʔpaʔnieyɔǝk roat~roattʰaʔ mʊəntrəy/ (ឧបនាយករដ្ឋមន្ត្រី; upanāyaka raṭṭha mantrī): Deputy Prime Minister<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sealang.net/api/api.pl?query=%E1%9E%A7%E1%9E%94%E1%9E%93%E1%9E%B6%E1%9E%99%E1%9E%80%E1%9E%9A%E1%9E%8A%E1%9F%92%E1%9E%8B%E1%9E%98%E1%9E%93%E1%9F%92%E1%9E%8F%E1%9F%92%E1%9E%9A%E1%9E%B8&service=dictionary|title=SEAlang Dictionary|website=sealang.net|language=en|access-date=2018-06-13}}</ref> */roattʰaʔmʊəntrəy/ (រដ្ឋមន្ត្រី; raṭṭha mantrī): Minister<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sealang.net/api/api.pl?query=%E1%9E%9A%E1%9E%8A%E1%9F%92%E1%9E%8B%E1%9E%98%E1%9E%93%E1%9F%92%E1%9E%8F%E1%9F%92%E1%9E%9A%E1%9E%B8&service=dictionary|title=SEAlang Dictionary|website=sealang.net|language=en|access-date=2018-06-13}}</ref> */keaʔnaʔroattʰaʔmʊəntrəy/(គណៈរដ្ឋមន្ត្រី; gaṇa raṭṭha mantrī): Council of Ministers<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sealang.net/api/api.pl?query=%E1%9E%82%E1%9E%8E%E1%9F%88%E1%9E%9A%E1%9E%8A%E1%9F%92%E1%9E%8B%E1%9E%98%E1%9E%93%E1%9F%92%E1%9E%8F%E1%9F%92%E1%9E%9A%E1%9E%B8&service=dictionary|title=SEAlang Dictionary|website=sealang.net|language=en|access-date=2018-06-13}}</ref> */mʊəntrəy/ (មន្ត្រី, mantrī): official, minister, counsellor<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sealang.net/api/api.pl?query=%E1%9E%98%E1%9E%93%E1%9F%92%E1%9E%8F%E1%9F%92%E1%9E%9A%E1%9E%B8&service=dictionary|title=SEAlang Dictionary|website=sealang.net|language=en|access-date=2018-06-13}}</ref>
===Indonesia=== * Mantri, in the form of '''Menteri''' is a Sanskrit loanword that describes ministers of the government. '''Perdana Menteri''' (corresponding exactly to [[Pradhan]] Mantri) is used to describe [[prime ministers]] (as Indonesia is a presidential country, it is mainly used to describe prime ministers of other countries adopting the parliamentary system). *in [[Buleleng]] Mantri occurred (rank unclear) *in [[Sultanate of Deli|Deli]] the title of ''Tengku Perdana Mantri'' was created 1 February 1923 for Y.A.M. Tengku Harun al-Rashid ibni al-Marhum Sultan Ma'amun al-Rashid Perkasa 'Alam Shah, eldest brother of the Crown Prince (Sultan the next year) and [[Wakil]] of [[Bedagai]] 1932 *in [[Kutai]], '''Perdana-mantri''' was the first great Officer of state, or Chief Minister *in [[Sultanate of Sambas|Sambas]], '''Radin Mantri''' was a high stles for princes of the blood, e.g. borne by H.H. Sri Paduka al-Sultan Tuanku 'Abu Bakar Taj ud-din I [al-Marhum Janggut] ibni al-Marhum Sultan 'Umar Akam ud-din, future Sultan of Sambas, before his accession on the death of his father, 1790 *in [[Yogyakarta]] and [[Surakarta]] palaces - the term is part of administrative titles for positions within the palaces and places that they control.
===Malaysia=== *Perdana Menteri: Prime Minister *Timbalan Perdana Menteri: Deputy Prime Minister *Menteri: Minister *Jemaah Menteri: Cabinet *in various constitutive [[sultanate]]s, also in compounds
===Thailand=== *Nayok Rattha Montri (นายกรัฐมนตรี): Prime Minister *Rawng Nayok Rattha Montri (รองนายกรัฐมนตรี): Deputy Prime Minister *Rattha Montri Waa Kan (รัฐมนตรีว่าการ): Minister *Khana Rattha Montri (คณะรัฐมนตรี): Cabinet
==Sources and references== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.4dw.net/royalark/index.html RoyalArk - choose present country, the, historical state/dynasty]
{{asia-hist-stub}} [[Category:Executive ministers]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = National Day |type = |image = |imagesize = |caption = |official_name = |nickname = |observedby = [[Cameroon]] |litcolor = |longtype = |significance = |begins = |ends = |date = 20 May |celebrations = |observances = |relatedto = |scheduling = same day each year |duration = 1 day |frequency = annual }} '''National Day''' is a [[holiday]] in [[Cameroon]] celebrated on 20 May. On the 20th of May 1972, in a national [[Cameroonian constitutional referendum, 1972|referendum]] Cameroonians voted for a unitary state as opposed to the existing federal state. The [[United Nations Trust Territory]] known as [[French Cameroun]] achieved independence from France on 1 January 1960, and British [[Southern Cameroons]] changed status from a Trusteeship under British administration to a [[federation|federated]] state within Cameroon on 1 October 1961. The government chose 20 May as Cameroon's National Day to commemorate President [[Ahmadou Ahidjo]]'s abolishment of the federal system of government in favor of a [[unitary state|unitary country]] in 1972.
Even though it is considered a holiday, children all over the country go to schools and celebrate [[National Day]] usually by singing, carrying out parades or marches all around the different parts of their various cities. Speeches are made by the [[Head of State]] and other important personalities. The day is presided over by the head of state in Yaounde the capital of Cameroon. In the regional headquarters, it is presided by the governor who represents the government. The divisional officers preside over the day in their various divisions.
==References== * Mbaku, John Mukum (2005). ''Culture and Customs of Cameroon''. Westport, Connecticut: Greenwood Press.
[[Category:Cameroonian culture]] [[Category:National days]] [[Category:May observances]]
{{Cameroon-stub}} {{Holiday-stub}}

revision.comment: Reverted to revision 840152782 by [[Special:Contributions/98.212.146.82|98.212.146.82]] ([[User talk:98.212.146.82|talk]]): Rv/v. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{one source|date=November 2011}} [[File:Jorge Afonso 01.jpg|thumbnail|Annunciation, by [[Jorge Afonso]] ]]
'''Portuguese art''' includes many different styles from many different eras.
==Sculptures== Portuguese sculptures can be best analysed by studying the many [[tomb]]s of the 12th and 13th Centuries that are found throughout [[Portugal]]. In the late 1700s, the [[Colonal Brazil|colony of Brazil]] was the main influence in Portuguese [[sculpture]]. This can be seen by the increase in [[Baroque sculpture|Baroque]] wooden sculptures during this time. [[Joaquim Machado de Castro]], a famous Portuguese artist who lived around this time, is responsible for a lot of these works.<ref name="portugal-live">[http://www.portugal-live.net/UK/essential/culture-arts.html Portugal-Live.net]</ref>
==Painting== [[File:GraoVasco.jpg|thumbnail|The Last Supper, [[Grão Vasco]]]] The Classical and Romantic styles of [[painting]], brought to Portugal from [[Italy]] and [[France]], had an influence on Portuguese artist [[Machado de Castro]] in the late 18th century and [[António Soares dos Reis]] in the 19th century. A school for amateur painters, led by [[Nuno Gonçalves]], was popular in the 15th century. As a result, [[Flemish]] artists added to the native style by decorating palaces and convents using their own techniques. The result gave Portugal a rich heritage of [[religious art]]. The Romantic Period in the 19th century sparked a rebirth of national art. This was followed by an era of naturalist realism, which in turn was followed by experimentation the 20th century.<ref name="portugal-live" />
==Contemporary artists== Many Portuguese contemporary artists have made their mark on the world stage. [[Maria Helena Vieira de Silva]] was a famous Portuguese abstract painter and [[Carlos Botelho (painter)|Carlos Botelho]] was known for his street scenes of [[Lisbon]]. [[Paula Rego]] is known for her "storytelling" in painting. She became famous for her works "Dog Woman" (1990’s), and "Abortion", a reaction to the referendum in Portugal which made [[abortion]] a crime (late 1990s). Her art has been shown in museums such as [[Tate Modern]] in London and Casa das Histórias Paula Rego, in [[Cascais]] (dedicated solely to her art).<ref name="portugal-live" />
==Azulejos== The Portuguese glazed tiles ([[azulejo]]s) are one of Portugal's best decorative arts. Many 16th and 17th century buildings are lined with tiles, and the rooms and halls of palaces and mansions have tilted panels following a colour motif. Some prime examples of this style of art are the [[Pátio da Carranca]] (courtyard of Carranca) of the [[Paço de Sintra]] (Palace of Sintra), the [[Igreja de São Roque (Lisbon)|São Roque]] church in Lisbon and the [[Quinta da Bacalhoa]] at [[Vila Fresca de Azeitão]] near [[Setúbal]].<ref name="portugal-live" />
==References== {{reflist}} {{European topic|| art}}
[[Category:Portuguese art| ]]
{{Portugal-stub}} {{Art-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox diocese |jurisdiction = Diocese |name = Transfiguration at Novosibirsk |latin = Dioecesis Neosiberiana Transfigurationis |local = Преображенской епархии в Новосибирске |image = NovosibirskCatholicCathedral-2.jpg |caption = Cathedral of Transfiguration |country = [[Russia]] |metropolitan = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Mother of God at Moscow|Mother of God at Moscow]] |rite = [[Latin Rite]] |cathedral = Cathedral of Transfiguration |cocathedral = |area_km2 = 2,000,000 |population = 25,000,000 |population_as_of = 2010 |catholics = 500,000 |catholics_percent= 2.0 |pope = {{Incumbent pope}} |bishop = [[Joseph Werth]], [[Society of Jesus|S.J.]] |coadjutor = |auxiliary_bishops= |map = Roman Catholic Diocese of Transfiguration at Novosibirsk.PNG }}
The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Transfiguration at Novosibirsk''' ({{lang-la|Neosiberian(a) Transfigurationis}}) is a [[suffragan]] Latin [[diocese]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of the Metropolitan [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Mother of God at Moscow|Archbishop of Mother of God at Moscow]].
Its [[cathedral]] episcopal see is the Cathedral of the [[Transfiguration of Jesus|Transfiguration]], in the city of [[Novosibirsk]], in Asian [[Siberia]], Russia.
== History == * Established on April 13, 1991 as '''[[Apostolic Administration]] of Novosibirsk''', on territory split off from the [[Diocese of Vladivostok]] and the newly suppressed [[Metropolitan Archdiocese of Mohilev]] * Renamed on May 18, 1999 as '''Apostolic Administration of Western Siberia''', having lost territory to establish the then [[Apostolic Administration of Eastern Siberia]] (now Diocese of Saint Joseph at Irkutsk) * Promoted and renamed-back on February 11, 2002 as '''Diocese of Transfiguration at Novosibirsk'''
== Ordinaries == (all [[Roman rite]], so far missionary members of Latin congregations)
; ''Apostolic Administrators of Novosibirsk (Siberia) * Joseph Werth, [[Jesuits]] (S.J.), (1991.04.13 – 1999.05.18 ''see below''), [[Titular Bishop]] of [[Bulna]] (1991.04.13 – 2002.02.11) * [[Jerzy Mazur]], [[Divine Word Missionaries]] (S.V.D.) (1998.03.23 – 1999.05.18), Titular Bishop of [[Tabunia]] (1998.03.23 – 2002.02.11), later [[Apostolic Administrator]] of [[Apostolic Administration of Eastern Siberia|Eastern Siberia]] (Russia) (1999.05.18 – 2002.02.11), Apostolic Administrator of [[Apostolic Prefecture of Yuzhno Sakhalinsk|Yuzhno Sakhalinsk]] (Russia) (2000 – 2003.04.17), Bishop of [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Saint Joseph at Irkutsk|Saint Joseph at Irkutsk]] (Russia) (2002.02.11 – 2003.04.17), Bishop of [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Ełk|Ełk]] (Poland) (2003.04.17 – ...)
; Apostolic Administrator of ''Western Siberia * Joseph Werth, S.J. (''see above'' 1999.05.18 – 2002.02.11 ''see below)
; ''Suffragan Bishops of (Transfiguration at) Novosibirsk * Joseph Werth, S.J. (''see above'' 2002.02.11 - ...), President of Conference of Catholic Bishops of Russia (2005.02 – 2011.01.19)
== Statistics == As per 2014, it pastorally served 512,000 Catholics (2.0% of 25,600,000 total) on 2,000,000 km² in 70 parishes and 160 missions with 38 priests (19 diocesan, 19 religious), 1 deacon and 77 lay religious (20 brothers, 57 sisters).
Dependent churches include: * [[Holy Trinity Church, Tobolsk]]
== See also == * [[Roman Catholicism in Russia]]
== Sources and external links == * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/tran1.htm GCatholic.org, with Google satellite photo] * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dnovo.html Catholic Hierarchy] * [http://sibcatholic.ru/siberian-catholic-newspaper/ Siberian Catholic Newspaper - website of the press service of the Diocese of Transfiguration at Novosibirsk] * [http://nskcathedral.ru/catholic-church-in-western-siberia/ Catholic Church in Western Siberia] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071207173441/http://www.prijut.ru/english/ St. Nicholas Catholic Orphanage in Novosibirsk]
{{Coord missing|Russia}}

{{Infobox diocese |jurisdiction = Diocese |name = Weetebula |latin = Dioecesis Veetebulaensis |local = Keuskupan Weetebula |country = [[Indonesia]] |metropolitan = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Kupang|Kupang]] |province = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Kupang|Kupang]] |rite = [[Latin Rite]] |cathedral = Cathedral of the Holy Spirit in [[East Nusa Tenggara]] |cocathedral = |area_km2 = 11,052 |population = 644,000 |population_as_of = 2010 |catholics = 149,675 |catholics_percent= 23.2 |pope = {{Incumbent pope}} |bishop = Edmund Woga |metro_archbishop = Peter Turang |coadjutor = |auxiliary_bishops= }}
The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Weetebula''' ({{lang-la| Veetebulaen(sis)}}) is a [[suffragan]] Latin [[diocese]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of the Metropolitan of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Kupang|Kupang]] in [[Indonesia]]. It pastorally serves all of [[Sumba]] Island.
Its [[cathedral]] episcopal see is Katedral Roh Kudus, located in the city of [[Weetebula]], [[Nusa Tenggara Timur]].
== History == * Established on October 20, 1959 as the '''[[Apostolic Prefecture]] of Weetebula''', on territory split off from the then [[Apostolic Vicariate of Endeh]] (now a Metropolitan Archdiocese) * Promoted on February 6, 1969 as '''Diocese of Weetebula'''.
== Ordinaries == ''(all [[Roman Rite]], so far missionary members of Latin congregations)
;'' Apostolic Prefects of Weetebula * Fr. Gerard J. Legeland, [[Holy Ghost Fathers]] (C.SS.R.) (March 15, 1960 – death 1969) *''[[Apostolic Administrator]] (1969 – 1975) Fr. Wilhelm Wagener, C.SS.R. *''[[Apostolic Administrator]] (1975 – 1980) Fr. Henricus Haripranata, [[Society of Jesus]] (S.J.)
;''Suffragan Bishops of Weetebula * [[Gerulfus Kherubim Pareira]], [[Divine Word Missionaries]] (S.V.D.) (December 21, 1985 – January 19, 2008), later Bishop of [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Maumere|Maumere]] (Indonesia) (2008.01.19 – ...) * Edmund Woga, C.SS.R. (July 16, 2009 - ...)
==Sources and external links== * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/weet0.htm GCatholic.org] * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dweet.html Catholic Hierarchy]

revision.text:
{{For|the channel based in Italy|[[:it:Telenorba|Telenorba Italia]]}} {{For|the defunct channel based in Albania occupying the same UHF frequency since 25 October 2010|ABC News (Albania)}} {{Orphan|date=February 2017}}
{{Infobox company | name = TeleNorba (Shqiptare/Albanian/Albanese) | logo = | location_city = [[Tirana]] | location_country = [[Albania]] | area_served = [[Europe]], [[Albania]] | industry = [[Telecommunication]], [[Publishing]] | parent = [[:it:Telenorba|Telenorba Italia]] | homepage = [http://www.tnsh.tv/ www.tnsh.tv (defunct)] | footnotes = | intl = }} '''TeleNorba''' or '''Telenorba Shqiptare''' or simply '''TNSH''' (now '''ABC News''')<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kkrt.gov.al/sq/rreth-kkrt/njoftim-per-shtypin/160-24092010-njoftim-per-shtyp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101010143531/http://www.kkrt.gov.al/sq/rreth-kkrt/njoftim-per-shtypin/160-24092010-njoftim-per-shtyp |archivedate=2010-10-10 |df= }} Njoftim per Shtyp, KKRT, September 24, 2010</ref> is a defunct private Albanian TV channel from Tirana, Albania owned by the [[Bari]] based TeleNorba Italia broadcaster. At first, it was owned by Italian businessmen, then a Greek businessman and finally by Albanian media mogul Aleksander Frangaj. The channel launched in 1997/8 in Albania and used to be available via analogue in central Albania and later on satellite in Europe on the Albanian TV package [[DigitAlb]].
Traditionally, the channel broadcast a variety of programming but its core focus remained news programming and soap operas from Italy. In 2002, it was ranked fourth with 11.3% audience share. TeleNorba was the only affiliated channel to [[TV Klan]] which had the right to broadcast Njerez te humbur (Missing people) but did not hold the rights to broadcast the program live. Indeed, the program debuted on TNSH.<ref>http://tvklan.blogspot.com/2009/04/njerez-te-humbur.html TV Klan Blog</ref> On October 25, 2010, after some successful take overs from imminent bankruptcy, the channel was rebranded to [[ABC News (Albania)|ABC News]].
== History == Due to the success of Italian media worldwide and their reach in Albania, the broadcaster decided to launch a new channel called Telenorba which would broadcast Italian programming to Albanian audiences. The ownership was made up of Italian and Albanian businessmen and a private company. Afterwards, it rebranded to "TeleNorba Shqiptare or TNSH" while programmes started to be subtitled in the [[Albanian language]]. Colpo Grosso, a late night adult show became a huge success together with soap operas from Latin America. The channel gained popularity and was able to expand its range of programing to include many Albanian programs and a high-profile news bulletin. At midnight, TNSH used to simulcast the Italian version of the channel.
== Satellite broadcasting == Despite having been one of the youngest channels created by the TeleNorba company, TeleNorba Shqiptare was the only channel to broadcast by satellite in Europe.
==Logo== The first logo was a white 'TN' symbol taken from the original Telenorba channel in Italy. An amber version followed, while later the letters 'SH' denoting "Shqiptare" were added as the colors were changed to transparent blue letters on white background. Finally, the logo was replaced with the transparent logo of the existing Italian channel.

{{Orphan|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox film | name = Une Affaire de nègres | image = | caption = | director = [[Osvalde Lewat|Osvalde Lewat-Hallade]] | producer = AMIP | writer = | starring = | distributor = | released = 2006 | runtime = 90 minutes | country = Cameroon
France | language = | budget = | gross = | screenplay = Osvalde Lewat-Hallade | cinematography = Philippe Radoux-Bazzani | editing = Danielle Azenin | music = }} '''''Une Affaire de nègres''''' is a 2006 documentary film. == Synopsis == March 20, 2000, a decree by the President of the Republic of [[Cameroon]] set up an Operational Command Unit to tackle rampant banditry in the [[Douala]] region. The Unit introduced what amounted to round-ups: in one year, 1600 people disappeared or were killed. One year later, nine young men disappeared. The matter was submitted to the [[UN High Commissioner for Human Rights]]. The accused were found guilty of "failure to follow orders" and released but legal proceedings have not come to an end. The victims' families have to live between the desire for justice and the pressure for the crimes to be wiped out forever from the collective memory. == References == {{RefFCAT|23}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Affaire De Negres, Une}} [[Category:2006 films]] [[Category:Cameroonian films]] [[Category:Cameroonian documentary films]] [[Category:2000s documentary films]] [[Category:French documentary films]] [[Category:Documentary films about African politics]] [[Category:Documentary films about war crimes]] {{Cameroon-film-stub}} {{poli-documentary-film-stub}}
